class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Economic and political union of European states</div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/EU_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="EU (disambiguation)">EU (disambiguation)</a>.</div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the European Union. For the various levels of integration within European Countries including EU Member States, see <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>.</div>\n<p style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">\xe2\x80\xa2&#160;Summer&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+1&#160;to&#160;UTC+3</span> (<a href="/wiki/Western_European_Summer_Time" title="Western European Summer Time">WEST</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time" title="Central European Summer Time">CEST</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_European_Summer_Time" title="Eastern European Summer Time">EEST</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"></th><td class="infobox-data"><i>(see also <a href="/wiki/Summer_Time_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Summer Time in Europe">Summer Time in Europe</a>)</i><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;c&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><div style="line-height:11pt"><b>Website</b><br /><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://europa.eu">europa<wbr />.eu</a></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The <b>European Union</b> (<b>EU</b>) is a political and economic union of <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">27 member states</a> that are located primarily in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Its members have a combined area of 4,233,255.3&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (1,634,469.0&#160;sq&#160;mi) and an estimated total population of about 447<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million. The EU has developed <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">an internal single market</a> through a standardised <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">system of laws</a> that apply in all member states in those matters, and only those matters, where members have agreed to act as one. EU policies aim to ensure the free movement of people, goods, services and capital within the internal market;<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Internal_Market_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Internal_Market-14">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> enact legislation in justice and home affairs; and maintain common policies on <a href="/wiki/Common_Commercial_Policy_(EU)" title="Common Commercial Policy (EU)">trade</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">fisheries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regional_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Regional policy of the European Union">regional development</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> Passport controls have been abolished for travel within the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Internal_borders_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Internal_borders-18">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">A monetary union</a> was established in 1999, coming into full force in 2002, and is composed of <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">19 EU member states</a> which use the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro currency</a>. The EU has often been described as a <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_generis" title="Sui generis">sui generis</a></i> political entity (without precedent or comparison).<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU and <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">European citizenship</a> were established when the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> came into force in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115-21">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The EU traces its origins to the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a> (ECSC) and the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), established, respectively, by the 1951 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1951)" title="Treaty of Paris (1951)">Treaty of Paris</a> and 1957 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a>. The original members of what came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> were the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">Inner Six</a>: Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a>. The Communities and their successors have grown in size by <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">the accession of new member states</a> and in power by the addition of policy areas to their remit. The United Kingdom became the first member state to <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">leave the EU</a><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> on 31 January 2020. Before this, three territories of member states had <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_from_the_European_Union" title="Withdrawal from the European Union">left the EU</a> or its forerunners. The latest major amendment to the constitutional basis of the EU, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>, came into force in 2009.\n</p><p>Containing some 5.8% of the world population in 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;d&#93;</a></sup> the EU had generated a nominal <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) of around <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$15.5</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion in 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-GDP_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDP-8">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> constituting approximately 18% of global <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (January 2021)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Additionally, all EU countries have a very high <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Development Program">United Nations Development Programme</a>. In 2012, the EU was awarded the <a href="/wiki/2012_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2012 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> Through the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>, the union has developed a role in <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_European_Union" title="Foreign relations of the European Union">external relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Military of the European Union">defence</a>. It maintains permanent <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="List of diplomatic missions of the European Union">diplomatic missions</a> throughout the world and <a href="/wiki/European_Union_and_the_United_Nations" title="European Union and the United Nations">represents itself</a> at the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_and_the_G7" title="European Union and the G7">G7</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. Due to its global influence, the European Union has been described by some scholars as an <a href="/wiki/European_Union_as_an_emerging_superpower" title="European Union as an emerging superpower">emerging superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCormick2007_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCormick2007-27">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc" class="tocnumber">10.1</span> <span class="toctext">Regional and local policy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-45"><a href="#Environment_and_climate"><span class="tocnumber">10.2</span> <span class="toctext">Environment and climate</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-46"><a href="#Education_and_research"><span class="tocnumber">10.3</span> <span class="toctext">Education and research</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-47"><a href="#Health_care_and_food_safety"><span class="tocnumber">10.4</span> <span class="toctext">Health care and food safety</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-48"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-49"><a href="#Sport"><span class="tocnumber">11.1</span> <span class="toctext">Sport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50"><a href="#Symbols"><span class="tocnumber">11.2</span> <span class="toctext">Symbols</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-51"><a href="#Media"><span class="tocnumber">11.3</span> <span class="toctext">Media</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-52"><a href="#Impact"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Impact</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-53"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">15</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-56"><a href="#Citations"><span class="tocnumber">15.1</span> <span class="toctext">Citations</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-57"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">15.2</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-58"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">16</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-59"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">17</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_European_Union" title="History of the European Union">History of the European Union</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">Treaties of the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a></div>\n<p>Since the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign</a> <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> countries have entered into treaties and thereby co-operated and harmonised policies (or <i>pooled sovereignty</i>) in an increasing number of areas, in the so-called <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration project</a> or the <i>construction of Europe</i> (<a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>: <i lang="fr">la construction europ\xc3\xa9enne</i>). The following timeline outlines the legal inception of the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">European Union</a> (EU)\xe2\x80\x94the principal framework for this unification. The EU inherited many of its present responsibilities from the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> (EC), which were founded in the 1950s in the spirit of the <a href="/wiki/Schuman_Declaration" title="Schuman Declaration">Schuman Declaration</a>.\n</p>\n<table cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td colspan="2" rowspan="8" style="white-space:nowrap; text-align:left; font-size:90%"><u>Legend:</u><br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span>S: signing<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span>F: entry into force<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span>T: termination<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span>E: expiry<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span><span style="background:orange; font-size:120%">&#160;</span> <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> supersession<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span>Rel. w/ EC/EU framework:<br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span><span class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.2em; height:1.2em; margin:1px 0; border:3px dotted gray; text-align:center; margin-right:4px">&#160;</span><i>de facto</i> inside</span><br /><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;</span><span class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-image:repeating-linear-gradient(90deg, #F5F5F5 0, #F5F5F5 3px, gainsboro 3px, gainsboro 6px); text-align:center; margin-right:4px">&#160;</span>outside</span>\n</td>\n<td rowspan="7">&#160;\n</td>\n<td colspan="2" rowspan="3" valign="bottom" style="text-align:left">&#160;\n</td>\n<td rowspan="2">&#160;\n</td>\n<td rowspan="2">&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td colspan="4" style="background:#003399; border-left:3px solid #003399; font-variant:small-caps"><a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe"><img alt="Flag of Europe.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/30px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png" decoding="async" width="30" height="20" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/45px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/60px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="810" data-file-height="540" /></a> <a class="mw-selflink selflink"><span style="color:white;">European Union</span></a> <span style="color:white;">(EU)</span>\n</td>\n<td rowspan="11" style="color:white; background:#003399; background-image: repeating-linear-gradient(95deg, transparent 0, transparent 70%, white 71%, white 100%), repeating-linear-gradient(85deg, transparent 0, transparent 70%, white 71%, white 100%); font-size:90%"><i>[</i><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_European_Union" title="History of the European Union"><span style="color:white; srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/45px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/60px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="810" data-file-height="540" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe"><span style="color:white">Council of Europe</span></a> <span style="color:white">(CoE)</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left">\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em !important;min-width:3.5em;max-width:3.5em;width:3.5em;overflow:hidden;border-left:1px solid #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: March 1947<br />F: 8 September 1947<br />E: 8 September 1997</i></span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em 1948<br />T: 30 June 2011</i></span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em treaties\xc2\xb9<br />S: 5 May/4 April 1949<br />F: 3 August/24 August 1949</i></span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em agreement</a>\xc2\xb9<br />S: 21 October 1959<br />F: 1 January 1960</i></span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em 1975</span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: vertical-ideographic;display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(180deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(180deg); transform: rotate(180deg);;-ms-transform: none ;padding-left:1px;text-align:left;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"><i><a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Treaty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area#The_Schengen_Agreement_and_the_Schengen_Convention" title="Schengen Area">Convention</a><br />S: 14 June 1985/19 June 1990<br />F: 26 March 1995</i></span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em !important;min-width:2.625em;max-width:2.625em;width:2.625em;overflow:hidden;border-left:1px solid #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: vertical-ideographic;display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(180deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(180deg); transform: rotate(180deg);;-ms-transform: none ;padding-left:1px;text-align:left;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"><a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>\xc2\xb2<sup>, </sup>\xe2\x81\xb4<br />S: 7 February 1992<br />F: 1 November 1993</span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em !important;min-width:2.625em;max-width:2.625em;width:2.625em;overflow:hidden;border-left:1px solid #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: vertical-ideographic;display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(180deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(180deg); transform: rotate(180deg);;-ms-transform: none ;padding-left:1px;text-align:left;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Amsterdam" title="Treaty of Amsterdam">Amsterdam Treaty</a><br />S: 2 October 1997<br />F: 1 May 1999</span></div>\n</td>\n<td class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em !important;min-width:2.625em;max-width:2.625em;width:2.625em;overflow:hidden;border-left:1px solid #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: vertical-ideographic;display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(180deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(180deg); transform: rotate(180deg);;-ms-transform: none ;padding-left:1px;text-align:left;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Nice" title="Treaty of Nice">Nice Treaty</a><br />S: 26 February 2001<br />F: 1 February 2003</span></div>\n</td>\n<td colspan="3" class="nowrap unsortable" style="line-height:99%;vertical-align:bottom;padding:.4em .4em .2em;background-position:50% .4em !important;min-width:2.625em;max-width:2.625em;width:2.625em;overflow:hidden;border-left:1px solid #C7C7C7; width:7%"><div style="-webkit-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -o-writing-mode: vertical-rl; -ms-writing-mode: tb-rl;writing-mode: tb-rl; writing-mode: vertical-rl; layout-flow: vertical-ideographic;display: inline-block; -ms-transform: rotate(180deg); -webkit-transform: rotate(180deg); transform: rotate(180deg);;-ms-transform: none ;padding-left:1px;text-align:left;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a>\xe2\x81\xb5<br />S: 13 December 2007<br />F: 1 December 2009</span></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" data-collapsetext="hide notes" data-expandtext="show notes" style="font-size: 85%;">\n<dl><dd>\xc2\xb9Although not EU treaties <i>per se</i>, these treaties affected the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="History of the Common Security and Defence Policy">development</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">EU defence arm</a>, a main part of the CFSP. The Franco-British alliance established by the Dunkirk Treaty was <i>de facto</i> superseded by WU. The CFSP pillar was bolstered by some of the security structures that had been established within the remit of the 1955 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brussels" title="Treaty of Brussels">Modified Brussels Treaty</a> (MBT). The Brussels Treaty was <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union#2009\xe2\x80\x932011:_Dissolution" title="Western European Union">terminated</a> in 2011, consequently dissolving the WEU, as the <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Consolidated_version_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union/Title_V:_General_Provisions_on_the_Union%27s_External_Action_Service_and_Specific_Provisions_on_the_Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy#Article_42" class="extiw" title="wikisource:Consolidated version of the Treaty on European Union/Title V: General Provisions on the Union&#39;s External Action Service and Specific Provisions on the Common Foreign and Security Policy">mutual defence clause</a> that the Lisbon Treaty provided for EU was considered to render the WEU superfluous. The EU thus <i>de facto</i> superseded the WEU.</dd>\n<dd>\xc2\xb2The treaties of Maastricht and Rome form the EU\'s <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">legal basis</a>, and are also referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_European_Union" title="Treaty on European Union">Treaty on European Union</a> (TEU) and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a> (TFEU), respectively. They are amended by secondary treaties.</dd>\n<dd>\xc2\xb3The <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> obtained common institutions and a shared <a href="/wiki/Legal_person" title="Legal person">legal personality</a> (i.e. ability to e.g. sign treaties in their own right).</dd>\n<dd>\xe2\x81\xb4Between the EU\'s founding in 1993 and consolidation in 2009, the union consisted of <a href="/wiki/Three_pillars_of_the_European_Union" title="Three pillars of the European Union">three pillars</a>, the first of which were the European Communities. The other two pillars consisted of additional areas of cooperation that had been added to the EU\'s remit.</dd>\n<dd>\xe2\x81\xb5The consolidation meant that the EU inherited the European Communities\' <a href="/wiki/Legal_person" title="Legal person">legal personality</a> and that the <a href="/wiki/Three_pillars_of_the_European_Union" title="Three pillars of the European Union">pillar system was abolished</a>, resulting in the EU framework as such covering all policy areas. Executive/legislative power in each area was instead determined by a <a href="/wiki/Template:EU_competences" class="mw-redirect" title="Template:EU competences">distribution of competencies</a> between <a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">EU institutions</a> and <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a>. This distribution, as well as treaty provisions for policy areas in which unanimity is required and <a href="/wiki/Double_majority#European_Union" title="Double majority">qualified majority voting</a> is possible, reflects the depth of EU integration as well as the EU\'s partly <a href="/wiki/Supranational_union" title="Supranational union">supranational</a> and partly <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmentalism" title="Intergovernmentalism">intergovernmental</a> nature.</dd>\n<dd>\xe2\x81\xb6Plans to establish a <a href="/wiki/Treaty_establishing_the_European_Political_Community" title="Treaty establishing the European Political Community">European Political Community</a> (EPC) were shelved following the French failure to ratify the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_establishing_the_European_Defence_Community" title="Treaty establishing the European Defence Community">Treaty establishing the European Defence Community</a> (EDC). The EPC would have combined the ECSC and the EDC.</dd></dl>\n</div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ideas_of_European_unity_before_1945" title="Ideas of European unity before 1945">Ideas of European unity before 1945</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Habsburg_dominions_1700.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Habsburg_dominions_1700.png/220px-Habsburg_dominions_1700.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Habsburg_dominions_1700.png/330px-Habsburg_dominions_1700.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Habsburg_dominions_1700.png/440px-Habsburg_dominions_1700.png 2x" data-file-width="1152" data-file-height="812" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Habsburg_dominions_1700.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Spanish and Austrian <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">Habsburg</a> European lands, c. 1700</div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_1812_map_en.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Europe_1812_map_en.png/220px-Europe_1812_map_en.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Europe_1812_map_en.png/330px-Europe_1812_map_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Europe_1812_map_en.png/440px-Europe_1812_map_en.png 2x" data-file-width="2284" data-file-height="1503" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_1812_map_en.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleonic empire">French-dominated Europe</a> in 1812</div></div></div>\n<p>During the centuries that followed the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of Rome</a> in 476, several European states viewed themselves as <i><a href="/wiki/Translatio_imperii" title="Translatio imperii">translatio imperii</a></i> ("transfer of rule") of the defunct <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankish Empire">Frankish Empire</a> (481\xe2\x80\x93843) and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> (962\xe2\x80\x931806) were thereby attempts to resurrect <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Rome in the West</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;e&#93;</a></sup> This political philosophy of a supra-national rule over the continent, similar to the example of the ancient Roman Empire, resulted in the early Middle Ages in the concept of a <i><a href="/wiki/Renovatio_imperii_Romanorum" title="Renovatio imperii Romanorum">renovatio imperii</a></i> ("restoration of the empire"),<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> either in the forms of the <i>Reichsidee</i> ("imperial idea")<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> or the religiously inspired <i>Imperium Christianum</i> ("christian empire").<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> Medieval <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a> and the political power of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Papacy</a> have been cited as conducive to European integration and unity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200289_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200289-37">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMather200616\xe2\x80\x9318_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMather200616\xe2\x80\x9318-38">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles#Stay_on_topic" title="Wikipedia:Writing better articles"><span title="The material near this tag may contain information that is not relevant to the article&#39;s main topic. Are we really saying that the (remnants of) the Roman/Frankish Empires were about European unity? Unity through invasion isn&#39;t really unity... (December 2020)">relevant?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>In the oriental parts of the continent, the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russian Tsardom</a>, and ultimately the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Empire</a> (1547\xe2\x80\x931917), declared Moscow to be <a href="/wiki/Moscow,_third_Rome" title="Moscow, third Rome">Third Rome</a> and inheritor of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Eastern tradition</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> The gap between <a href="/wiki/Greek_East_and_Latin_West" title="Greek East and Latin West">Greek East and Latin West</a> had already been widened by the political scission&#160;of the Roman Empire in the 4th century and the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East\xe2\x80\x93West Schism">Great Schism of 1054</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200260,_75_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200260,_75-42">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> and would be eventually widened again by the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> (1945\xe2\x80\x931991) before the enlargement of the European Union towards Eastern Europe since 2004 onward.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonBort20011\xe2\x80\x932_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonBort20011\xe2\x80\x932-45">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO&#39;Brennan20061\xe2\x80\x932_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO&#39;Brennan20061\xe2\x80\x932-46">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles#Stay_on_topic" title="Wikipedia:Writing better articles"><span title="The material near this tag may contain information that is not relevant to the article&#39;s main topic. Are we really saying that the (remnants of) more empires were about European unity? Russia isn&#39;t in the EU; the Baltic states would disagree with the idea that the Soviet Union was inspired by a model of European unity... (December 2020)">relevant?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>Pan-European political thought truly emerged during the 19th century, inspired by the liberal ideas of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolutions</a> after the demise of <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">Napol\xc3\xa9on\'s Empire</a> (1804\xe2\x80\x931815). In the decades following the outcomes of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> ideals of European unity flourished across the continent, especially in the writings of <a href="/wiki/Wojciech_Jastrz%C4%99bowski" title="Wojciech Jastrz\xc4\x99bowski">Wojciech Jastrz\xc4\x99bowski</a> (1799\xe2\x80\x931882)<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Mazzini" title="Giuseppe Mazzini">Giuseppe Mazzini</a> (1805\xe2\x80\x931872).<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> The term <i><a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Europe" title="United States of Europe">United States of Europe</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>: <i lang="fr">\xc3\x89tats-Unis d\'Europe</i>) was used at that time by <a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">Victor Hugo</a> (1802\xe2\x80\x931885) during a speech at the <a href="/wiki/International_Peace_Congress" title="International Peace Congress">International Peace Congress</a> held in Paris in 1849:\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>A day will come when all nations on our continent will form a European brotherhood ... A day will come when we shall see ... the United States of America and the United States of Europe face to face, reaching out for each other across the seas.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">interwar period</a>, the consciousness that national markets in Europe were interdependent though confrontational, along with the observation of a larger and growing US market on the other side of the ocean, nourished the urge for the economic integration of the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaiserVarsori2010140_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaiserVarsori2010140-51">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> In 1920, advocating the creation of a European <a href="/wiki/Economic_union" title="Economic union">economic union</a>, British economist <a href="/wiki/John_Maynard_Keynes" title="John Maynard Keynes">John Maynard Keynes</a> wrote that "a Free Trade Union should be established ... to impose no protectionist tariffs whatever against the produce of other members of the Union."<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> During the same decade, <a href="/wiki/Richard_von_Coudenhove-Kalergi" title="Richard von Coudenhove-Kalergi">Richard von Coudenhove-Kalergi</a>, one of the first to imagine of a modern political union of Europe, founded the <a href="/wiki/Paneuropean_Union" title="Paneuropean Union">Pan-Europa Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERosamond200021\xe2\x80\x9322_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERosamond200021\xe2\x80\x9322-53">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> His ideas influenced his contemporaries, among which then <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France" title="Prime Minister of France">Prime Minister of France</a> <a href="/wiki/Aristide_Briand" title="Aristide Briand">Aristide Briand</a>. In 1929, the latter gave a speech in favour of a European Union before the assembly of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>, precursor of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWeigallStirk199211\xe2\x80\x9315_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWeigallStirk199211\xe2\x80\x9315-54">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> In a radio address in March 1943, with war still raging, Britain\'s leader Sir <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> spoke warmly of "restoring the true greatness of Europe" once victory had been achieved, and mused on the post-war creation of a "Council of Europe" which would bring the European nations together to build peace.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Preliminary_.281945.E2.80.931957.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Preliminary_(1945\xe2\x80\x931957)">Preliminary (1945\xe2\x80\x931957)</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht,_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/220px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/330px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/440px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3397" data-file-height="2854" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht,_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Meeting in the <a href="/wiki/Ridderzaal" title="Ridderzaal">Hall of Knights</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a>, during the congress (9 May 1948)</div></div></div>\n<p>After World War II, <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a> was seen as an antidote to the extreme nationalism which had devastated parts of the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> In a speech delivered on 19 September 1946 at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Z%C3%BCrich" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Z\xc3\xbcrich">University of Z\xc3\xbcrich</a>, Switzerland, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> went further and advocated the emergence of a <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Europe" title="United States of Europe">United States of Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> The 1948 <a href="/wiki/Hague_Congress_(1948)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hague Congress (1948)">Hague Congress</a> was a pivotal moment in European federal history, as it led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/European_Movement_International" title="European Movement International">European Movement International</a> and of the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Europe" title="College of Europe">College of Europe</a>, where Europe\'s future leaders would live and study together.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>It also led directly to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1949, the first great effort to bring the nations of Europe together, initially ten of them. The Council focused primarily on values\xe2\x80\x94human rights and democracy\xe2\x80\x94rather than on economic or trade issues, and was always envisaged as a forum where sovereign governments could choose to work together, with no supra-national authority. It raised great hopes of further European integration, and there were fevered debates in the two years that followed as to how this could be achieved.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><div id="mwe_player_1" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:220px;" videopayload="&lt;div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot; style=&quot;width:384px&quot;&gt;&lt;video id=&quot;mwe_player_2&quot; poster=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg/384px--Schuman_Declaration.ogg.jpg&quot; controls=&quot;&quot; preload=&quot;none&quot; autoplay=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;width:384px;height:288px&quot; class=&quot;kskin&quot; data-durationhint=&quot;27.92&quot; data-startoffset=&quot;0&quot; data-mwtitle=&quot;Schuman_Declaration.ogg&quot; data-mwprovider=&quot;local&quot;&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg&quot; type=&quot;video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;theora, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Original Ogg file, 384 \xc3\x97 288 (588 kbps)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;Ogg source&quot; data-width=&quot;384&quot; data-height=&quot;288&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;587607&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=bg&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;bg&quot; label=&quot;\xd0\xb1\xd1\x8a\xd0\xbb\xd0\xb3\xd0\xb0\xd1\x80\xd1\x81\xd0\xba\xd0\xb8 (bg)&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=en&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;en&quot; label=&quot;English (en)&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=eu&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;eu&quot; label=&quot;euskara (eu)&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=fr&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;fr&quot; label=&quot;fran\xc3\xa7ais (fr)&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"><img alt="File:Schuman Declaration.ogg" style="width:220px;height:165px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg/220px-seek%3D23-Schuman_Declaration.ogg.jpg" /><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Schuman_Declaration.ogg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Robert_Schuman" title="Robert Schuman">Robert Schuman</a> <a href="/wiki/Schuman_Declaration" title="Schuman Declaration">proposing</a> the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">Coal and Steel Community</a> on <a href="/wiki/Europe_Day" title="Europe Day">9 May</a> 1950</div></div></div>\n<p>But in 1952, disappointed at what they saw as the lack of progress within the Council of Europe, six nations decided to go further and created the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>, which was declared to be "a first step in the federation of Europe".<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> This community helped to economically integrate and coordinate the large number of <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> funds from the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> European leaders <a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">Alcide De Gasperi</a> from Italy, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Monnet" title="Jean Monnet">Jean Monnet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Schuman" title="Robert Schuman">Robert Schuman</a> from France, and <a href="/wiki/Paul-Henri_Spaak" title="Paul-Henri Spaak">Paul-Henri Spaak</a> from Belgium understood that coal and steel were the two industries essential for waging war, and believed that by tying their national industries together, future war between their nations became much less likely.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_45-59_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_45-59-62">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> These men and others are officially credited as the <a href="/wiki/Founding_fathers_of_the_European_Union" title="Founding fathers of the European Union">founding fathers of the European Union</a>.\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Treaty_of_Rome_.281957.E2.80.931992.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Treaty_of_Rome_(1957\xe2\x80\x931992)">Treaty of Rome (1957\xe2\x80\x931992)</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/220px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/330px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/440px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="520" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The continental territories of the member states of the European Union (European Communities pre-1993), coloured in order of accession</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1957, Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and West Germany signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a>, which created the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC) and established a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">customs union</a>. They also signed another pact creating the <a href="/wiki/European_Atomic_Energy_Community" title="European Atomic Energy Community">European Atomic Energy Community</a> (Euratom) for co-operation in developing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear energy</a>. Both treaties came into force in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_45-59_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_45-59-62">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EEC and Euratom were created separately from the ECSC and they shared the same courts and the Common Assembly. The EEC was headed by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Hallstein" title="Walter Hallstein">Walter Hallstein</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hallstein_Commission" title="Hallstein Commission">Hallstein Commission</a>) and Euratom was headed by <a href="/wiki/Louis_Armand" title="Louis Armand">Louis Armand</a> (<a href="/wiki/Armand_Commission" title="Armand Commission">Armand Commission</a>) and then <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tienne_Hirsch" title="\xc3\x89tienne Hirsch">\xc3\x89tienne Hirsch</a>. Euratom was to integrate sectors in nuclear energy while the EEC would develop a customs union among members.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>During the 1960s, tensions began to show, with France seeking to limit supranational power. Nevertheless, in 1965 an agreement was reached and on 1 July 1967 the <a href="/wiki/Merger_Treaty" title="Merger Treaty">Merger Treaty</a> created a single set of institutions for the three communities, which were collectively referred to as the <i><a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_Merge_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_Merge-65">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jean_Rey_(politician)" title="Jean Rey (politician)">Jean Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">presided over</a> the first merged Commission (<a href="/wiki/Rey_Commission" title="Rey Commission">Rey Commission</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1973, the Communities were enlarged to include Denmark (including <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>, which later <a href="/wiki/1982_Greenlandic_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1982 Greenlandic European Communities membership referendum">left the Communities</a> in 1985, following a dispute over fishing rights), Ireland, and the <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_the_United_Kingdom_to_the_European_Communities" title="Accession of the United Kingdom to the European Communities">United Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_First_enlargement_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_First_enlargement-68">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> Norway had negotiated to join at the same time, but Norwegian voters rejected membership in a <a href="/wiki/1972_Norwegian_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1972 Norwegian European Communities membership referendum">referendum</a>. In 1979, the <a href="/wiki/1979_European_Parliament_election" title="1979 European Parliament election">first direct elections</a> to the European Parliament were held.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_New_Parliament_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_New_Parliament-69">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Greece joined in 1981, Portugal and Spain following in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_Enlargement_negotiations_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_Enlargement_negotiations-70">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> In 1985, the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> paved the way for the creation of open borders without passport controls between most member states and some non-member states.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> In 1986, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">European flag</a> began to be used by the EEC<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a> was signed.\n</p><p>In 1990, after <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">the fall of the Eastern Bloc</a>, the former <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> became part of the Communities as part of a <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">reunified Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_80-89_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_80-89-73">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Maastricht_Treaty_.281992.E2.80.932007.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Maastricht_Treaty_(1992\xe2\x80\x932007)">Maastricht Treaty (1992\xe2\x80\x932007)</span></h3>\n<p>The European Union was formally established when the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>\xe2\x80\x94whose main architects were <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Kohl" title="Helmut Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand">Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand</a>\xe2\x80\x94came into force on 1 November 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115-21">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The treaty also gave the name <a href="/wiki/European_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="European Community">European Community</a> to the EEC, even if it was referred as such before the treaty. With further enlargement planned to include the former <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist states</a> of Central and Eastern Europe, as well as <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">Copenhagen criteria</a> for candidate members to join the EU were agreed upon in June 1993. The expansion of the EU introduced a new level of complexity and discord.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-75">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> In 1995, Austria, Finland, and Sweden <a href="/wiki/1995_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="1995 enlargement of the European Union">joined</a> the EU.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Euro_Series_Banknotes_(2019).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg/220px-Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg/330px-Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg/440px-Euro_Series_Banknotes_%282019%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="554" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Euro_Series_Banknotes_(2019).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> was introduced in 2002, replacing 12 national currencies. Seven countries have since joined.</div></div></div>\n<p>In 2002, euro banknotes and coins replaced national currencies in 12 of the member states. Since then, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> has increased to encompass 19 countries. The euro currency became the second largest reserve currency in the world. In 2004, the EU saw <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">its biggest enlargement to date</a> when Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia joined the Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_00_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_00-76">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Lisbon_Treaty_.282007.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Lisbon_Treaty_(2007\xe2\x80\x93present)">Lisbon Treaty (2007\xe2\x80\x93present)</span></h3>\n<p>In 2007, Bulgaria and Romania became EU members. Later that year, Slovenia adopted the euro,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_00_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_00-76">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> followed by Cyprus and Malta in 2008, Slovakia in 2009, Estonia in 2011, Latvia in 2014, and Lithuania in 2015.\n</p><p>On 1 December 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> entered into force and reformed many aspects of the EU. In particular, it changed the legal structure of the European Union, merging the <a href="/wiki/Three_pillars_of_the_European_Union" title="Three pillars of the European Union">EU three pillars</a> system into a single legal entity provisioned with a <a href="/wiki/Legal_personality" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal personality">legal personality</a>, created a permanent <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, the first of which was <a href="/wiki/Herman_Van_Rompuy" title="Herman Van Rompuy">Herman Van Rompuy</a>, and strengthened the position of the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPiris2010448_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiris2010448-77">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2012, the EU received the <a href="/wiki/2012_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2012 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> for having "contributed to the advancement of peace and reconciliation, democracy, and human rights in Europe."<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> became the 28th EU member.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>From the beginning of the 2010s, the cohesion of the European Union has been tested by several issues, including <a href="/wiki/European_debt_crisis" title="European debt crisis">a debt crisis in some of the Eurozone countries</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis" title="European migrant crisis">increasing migration from Africa and Asia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">United Kingdom\'s withdrawal from the EU</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCUKREFRESLT_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCUKREFRESLT-82">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">referendum in the UK on its membership of the European Union</a> was held in 2016, with 51.9% of participants voting to leave.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTEUBrexit_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTEUBrexit-83">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> The UK formally notified the European Council of its decision to leave on 29 March 2017, initiating the <a href="/wiki/Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">formal withdrawal procedure for leaving the EU</a>; following extensions to the process, the UK left the European Union on 31 January 2020, though most areas of EU law continued to apply to the UK for a transition period which lasted until 23:00 GMT on 31 December 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_European_Union" title="Demographics of the European Union">Demographics of the European Union</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Population">Population</span></h3>\n<p>As of 1&#160;February&#160;2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Union&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the population of the European Union was about 447&#160;million people (5.8% of the world population).<sup id="cite_ref-population_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-population-85">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> In 2015, 5.1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million children were born in the EU-28 corresponding to a birth rate of 10 per 1,000, which is 8 births below the world average.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> For comparison, the EU-28 birth rate had stood at 10.6 in 2000, 12.8 in 1985 and 16.3 in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Its population growth rate was positive at an estimated 0.23% in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2010, 47.3<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million people who lived in the EU were born outside their resident country. This corresponds to 9.4% of the total EU population. Of these, 31.4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million (6.3%) were born outside the EU and 16.0<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million (3.2%) were born in another EU member state. The largest absolute numbers of people born outside the EU were in Germany (6.4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million), France (5.1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million), the United Kingdom (4.7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million), Spain (4.1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million), Italy (3.2<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million), and the Netherlands (1.4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million).<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> In 2017, approximately 825,000 people acquired <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">citizenship</a> of a member state of the European Union. The <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Europe" title="Immigration to Europe">largest groups</a> were nationals of Morocco, Albania, India, Turkey and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> 2.4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Europe" title="Immigration to Europe">immigrants</a> from non-EU countries entered the EU in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits" title="List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits">List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_European_Union" title="List of urban areas in the European Union">list of urban areas in the European Union</a></div>\n<p>The EU contains about 40 urban areas with populations of over 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million. With a population of over 13 million,<sup id="cite_ref-paris_AAV20_pop_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-paris_AAV20_pop-94">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> is the largest metropolitan area and the only <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a> in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat-95">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> Paris is followed by <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ruhr" title="Ruhr">Ruhr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>, all with a metropolitan population of over 4<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million.<sup id="cite_ref-appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu-96">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU also has numerous <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">polycentric</a> urbanised regions like <a href="/wiki/Rhine-Ruhr" title="Rhine-Ruhr">Rhine-Ruhr</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dortmund" title="Dortmund">Dortmund</a>, <a href="/wiki/D%C3%BCsseldorf" title="D\xc3\xbcsseldorf">D\xc3\xbcsseldorf</a> et al.), <a href="/wiki/Randstad" title="Randstad">Randstad</a> (<a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rotterdam" title="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a>, <a href="/wiki/Utrecht" title="Utrecht">Utrecht</a> et al.), <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Rhine-Main" title="Frankfurt Rhine-Main">Frankfurt Rhine-Main</a> (<a href="/wiki/Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wiesbaden" title="Wiesbaden">Wiesbaden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mainz" title="Mainz">Mainz</a> et al.), the <a href="/wiki/Flemish_Diamond" title="Flemish Diamond">Flemish Diamond</a> (<a href="/wiki/Antwerp" title="Antwerp">Antwerp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leuven" title="Leuven">Leuven</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghent" title="Ghent">Ghent</a> et al.) and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Silesian_metropolitan_area" title="Upper Silesian metropolitan area">Upper Silesian area</a> (<a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ostrava" title="Ostrava">Ostrava</a> et al.).<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat-95">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<table class="navbox" style="width: 100%">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0; line-height:1.4em;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">Languages of the European Union</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Euro_English" title="Euro English">Euro English</a></div>\n<table class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible floatright" style="border: 0.5em; font-size: 90%; line-height: 0.9em; max-width: 20em;">\n<caption>Official languages by percentage of speakers (as of February 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> based on 2012 survey<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup>)\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th scope="col" style="width: 60%;">Language\n</th>\n<th scope="col" style="width: 20%;"><a href="/wiki/First_language" href="#cite_note-102">&#91;g&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-totalLanguages_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-totalLanguages-103">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th
