language">Greek</a>\n</th>\n<td>3%\n</td>\n<td>4%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>\n</th>\n<td>3%\n</td>\n<td>3%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>\n</th>\n<td>2%\n</td>\n<td>3%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a>\n</th>\n<td>2%\n</td>\n<td>3%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</a>\n</th>\n<td>2%\n</td>\n<td>3%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>\n</th>\n<td>2%\n</td>\n<td>2%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>51%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>2%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">Finnish</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>\n</th>\n<td>1%\n</td>\n<td>1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>\n</th>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a>\n</th>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>\n</th>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>\n</th>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>\n</th>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td>\n<td>&lt;1%\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The European Union has 24 official languages: <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">Dutch</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">Finnish</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">Romanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</a>. Important documents, such as legislation, are translated into every official language and the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> provides translation for documents and plenary sessions.<sup id="cite_ref-Official_Languages_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Official_Languages-104">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Due to the high number of official languages, most of the institutions use only a handful of working languages. The European Commission conducts its internal business in three <i>procedural languages</i>: English, French, and German.<sup id="cite_ref-procedural_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-procedural-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Similarly, the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a> uses French as the working language,<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> conducts its business primarily in English.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Even though <a href="/wiki/Language_policy" title="Language policy">language policy</a> is the responsibility of member states, EU institutions promote multilingualism among its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;h&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> In 2012, English was the most widely spoken language in the EU, being understood by 51% of the EU population when counting both native and non-native speakers. However, following the UK\'s exit from the block in early 2020 the percentage of the EU population who spoke English as their native language fell from 13% to 1%.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> German is the most widely spoken mother tongue (18% of the EU population), and the second most widely understood foreign language, followed by French (13% of the EU population). In addition, both are official languages of several EU member states. More than half (56%) of EU citizens are able to engage in a conversation in a language other than their mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_Languages_P3_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_Languages_P3-112">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>A total of twenty official languages of the EU belong to the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a> <a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">language family</a>, represented by the <a href="/wiki/Balto-Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Balto-Slavic">Balto-Slavic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;i&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">Italic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;j&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Germanic Europe">Germanic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;k&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_languages" title="Hellenic languages">Hellenic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;l&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic</a><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;m&#93;</a></sup> branches. Only four languages, namely <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">Finnish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a> (all three <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a> (<a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a>), are not Indo-European languages.<sup id="cite_ref-Many_tongues,_one_family_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Many_tongues,_one_family-118">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> The three official alphabets of the European Union (<a href="/wiki/Cyrillic_script" title="Cyrillic script">Cyrillic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greek_alphabet" title="Greek alphabet">modern Greek</a>) all derive from the <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Greek_alphabets" title="Archaic Greek alphabets">Archaic Greek scripts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Luxembourgish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Luxembourgish language">Luxembourgish</a> (in Luxembourg) and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a> (in Cyprus) are the only two national languages that are not official languages of the EU. On 26 February 2016 it was made public that Cyprus has asked to make Turkish an official EU language, in a "gesture" that could help solve the <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">division of the country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> Already in 2004, it was planned that Turkish would become an official language when Cyprus reunites.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Besides the 24 official languages, there are about 150 <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minority languages</a>, spoken by up to 50&#160;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-Many_tongues,_one_family_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Many_tongues,_one_family-118">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">Galician</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> are not recognised official languages of the European Union but have official status in one member state (Spain): therefore, official translations of the treaties are made into them and citizens have the right to correspond with the institutions in these languages.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-122">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a> ratified by most EU states provides general guidelines that states can follow to protect their linguistic heritage. The <a href="/wiki/European_Day_of_Languages" title="European Day of Languages">European Day of Languages</a> is held annually on 26 September and is aimed at encouraging language learning across Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_European_Union" title="Religion in the European Union">Religion in the European Union</a></div>\n<table class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible plainrowheaders floatright" style="font-size: 90%;">\n<caption>Religious affiliation in the European Union (2015)<sup id="cite_ref-EB2015_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2015-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th scope="col">Affiliation\n</th>\n<th scope="colgroup" colspan="2">% of EU population\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">71.6\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">71.6</span><div style="width:143.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:darkblue">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;"><a href="/wiki/Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic">Catholic</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">45.3\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">45.3</span><div style="width:90.6px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightblue">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;"><a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">11.1\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">11.1</span><div style="width:22.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightblue">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;"><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">9.6\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">9.6</span><div style="width:19.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightblue">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;">Other Christian\n</th>\n<td align="right">5.6\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">5.6</span><div style="width:11.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightblue">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">1.8\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">1.8</span><div style="width:3.6px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:green">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row">Other faiths\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">2.6\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">2.6</span><div style="width:5.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:purple">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligious</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">24\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">24</span><div style="width:48px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:grey">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;">Non-believer/<a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">Agnostic</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">13.6\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">13.6</span><div style="width:27.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightgrey">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row" style="text-indent: 15px;"><a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">Atheist</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">10.4\n</td>\n<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">10.4</span><div style="width:20.8px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightgrey">&#160;</div>\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<p>The EU has no formal connection to any religion. The Article 17 of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> recognises the "status under national law of churches and religious associations" as well as that of "philosophical and non-confessional organisations".<sup id="cite_ref-Consolidated_Treaties_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consolidated_Treaties-126">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The preamble to the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Treaty on European Union</a> mentions the "cultural, religious and humanist inheritance of Europe".<sup id="cite_ref-Consolidated_Treaties_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consolidated_Treaties-126">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> Discussion over the draft texts of the European Constitution and later the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> included proposals to mention <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> or a <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">god</a>, or both, in the preamble of the text, but the idea faced opposition and was dropped.<sup id="cite_ref-EUO_Merkel_God_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUO_Merkel_God-127">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Christians in the European Union are divided among members of Catholicism (both <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Rite</a>), numerous <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations (<a href="/wiki/Anglicans" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglicans">Anglicans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutherans" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutherans">Lutherans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reformed" class="mw-redirect" title="Reformed">Reformed</a> forming the bulk of this category), and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>. In 2009, the EU had an estimated <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Muslim_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by Muslim population">Muslim population</a> of 13&#160;million,<sup id="cite_ref-mgmpPRC_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mgmpPRC-128">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> and an estimated <a href="/wiki/Jewish_population" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish population">Jewish population</a> of over a million.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> The other world religions of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> are also represented in the EU population.\n</p><p>According to new polls about religiosity in the European Union in 2015 by <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> is the largest religion in the European Union, accounting for 71.6% of the EU population. <a href="/wiki/Catholics" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholics">Catholics</a> are the largest Christian group, accounting for 45.3% of the EU population, while <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestants</a> make up 11.1%, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> make up 9.6%, and other Christians make up 5.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-EB2015_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2015-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer</a> opinion polls showed in 2005 that 52% of EU citizens believed in a god, 27% in "some sort of spirit or life force", and 18% had no form of belief.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-130">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> Many countries have experienced falling church attendance and membership in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-About_SecE_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About_SecE-131">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> The countries where the fewest people reported a religious belief were Estonia (16%) and the Czech Republic (19%).<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-130">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The most religious countries were Malta (95%, predominantly Catholic) as well as Cyprus and Romania (both predominantly Orthodox) each with about 90% of citizens professing a belief in their respective god. Across the EU, belief was higher among women, older people, those with religious upbringing, those who left school at 15 or 16, and those "positioning themselves on the right of the political scale".<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_130-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-130">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Member_states">Member states</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">Member state of the European Union</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:552px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_425bd3d353257b07"><area href="/wiki/Croatia" shape="poly" coords="358,224,367,229,375,229,385,222,382,212,388,209,383,202,366,195,347,200,347,217,360,217" alt="Lithuania" title="Lithuania" /><area href="/wiki/Poland" shape="poly" coords="373,246,366,226,361,224,336,228,330,229,329,223,311,226,309,231,296,236,296,245,291,248,297,253,300,278,310,280,312,285,317,281,325,286,330,289,334,292,336,295,340,292,343,299,350,295,352,295,360,294,368,301,370,297,370,291,375,278,380,276,378,270,375,266,368,250" alt="Poland" title="Poland" /><area href="/wiki/Slovakia" shape="poly" coords="316,311,320,305,325,304,335,294,338,292,343,299,347,296,360,292,370,302,341,311,335,315,335,320,322,316" alt="Slovakia" title="Slovakia" /><area href="/wiki/Hungary" shape="poly" coords="372,312,362,305,336,314,335,320,321,314,310,334,316,337,324,347,334,346,342,341,361,338,366,321" alt="Hungary" title="Hungary" /><area href="/wiki/Romania" shape="poly" coords="442,362,441,348,449,341,442,335,434,338,431,336,427,322,413,309,411,302,408,301,403,307,391,311,388,309,375,311,366,317,363,330,358,337,351,341,358,350,365,353,365,358,368,361,376,357,375,362,383,366,383,370,394,370,401,370,409,367,422,357,432,358" alt="France" title="France" /><area href="/wiki/Germany" shape="poly" coords="251,222,260,222,263,225,271,226,269,230,271,233,287,225,292,229,287,233,296,235,296,245,292,250,296,253,299,276,294,274,291,279,278,284,275,286,279,296,289,307,279,317,270,321,263,322,258,320,253,325,248,319,235,317,228,319,230,304,236,300,225,292,222,279,225,266,224,258,230,250,236,243,239,233,245,233,248,235,251,231" shape="poly" coords="193,261,195,274,207,280,218,289,215,281,222,280,220,268,213,261,204,264,199,260" alt="Belgium" title="Belgium" /><area href="/wiki/Netherlands" shape="poly" coords="238,234,222,235,202,260,208,260,213,258,212,261,223,268,224,258,234,254,229,249,234,246" alt="Netherlands" title="Netherlands" /><area href="/wiki/Denmark" shape="poly" coords="250,220,260,220,276,225,284,219,282,198,273,212,275,220,269,218,266,203,271,197,268,178,251,195" alt="Denmark" title="Denmark" /><area href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" shape="poly" coords="127,225,114,223,102,225,98,223,93,215,97,209,111,202,105,198,111,188,122,192,124,190,121,187,129,182,136,183,124,194,134,207,132,217,128,220" alt="Ireland" title="Ireland" /></map><img alt="" href="/wiki/File:Member_States_of_the_European_Union_(polar_stereographic_projection)_EN.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing the member states of the European Union (clickable)</div></div></div>\n<p>Through successive <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">enlargements</a>, the European Union has grown from the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">six founding states</a> (Belgium, France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands) to 27 members. Countries accede to the union by becoming party to the founding <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>, thereby subjecting themselves to the privileges and obligations of EU membership. This entails a partial delegation of sovereignty to the institutions in return for representation within those institutions, a practice often referred to as "pooling of sovereignty".<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>To become a member, a country must meet the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">Copenhagen criteria</a>, defined at the 1993 meeting of the European Council in Copenhagen. These require a stable democracy that respects human rights and the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a>; a functioning <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>; and the acceptance of the obligations of membership, including EU law. Evaluation of a country\'s fulfilment of the criteria is the responsibility of the European Council.<sup id="cite_ref-Accession_Criteria_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Accession_Criteria-134">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">Article 50</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> provides the basis for a member to <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_from_the_European_Union" title="Withdrawal from the European Union">leave the Union</a>. Two territories have left the Union: <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> (an <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous area">autonomous province</a> of Denmark) withdrew in 1985;<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> the United Kingdom formally invoked Article 50 of the Consolidated Treaty on European Union in 2017, and became the only sovereign state to leave when it <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">withdrew</a> from the EU in 2020.\n</p><p>There are six countries that are recognised as <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">candidates for membership</a>: <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Albania_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Albania to the European Union">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Iceland_to_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Accession of Iceland to the European Union">Iceland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_North_Macedonia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of North Macedonia to the European Union">North Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Montenegro_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Montenegro to the European Union">Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Serbia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Serbia to the European Union">Serbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">Turkey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Enlargement_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Enlargement-136">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> though Iceland suspended negotiations in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-icelandover_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icelandover-137">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Kosovo_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Kosovo to the European Union">Kosovo</a> are officially recognised as potential candidates,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Enlargement_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Enlargement-136">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> with Bosnia and Herzegovina having submitted a membership application.\n</p><p>The four countries forming the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA) are not EU members, but have partly committed to the EU\'s economy and regulations: Iceland, <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, which are a part of the <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">single market</a> through the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, which has similar ties through <a href="/wiki/Switzerland%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="Switzerland\xe2\x80\x93European Union relations">bilateral treaties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EEA_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EEA-138">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CH_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CH-139">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> The relationships of the <a href="/wiki/Microstates_and_the_European_Union" title="Microstates and the European Union">European microstates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">Andorra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">San Marino</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> include the use of the euro and other areas of co-operation.<sup id="cite_ref-euro_use_world_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euro_use_world-140">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align: center; white-space: data-sort-value="6996111000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>111/km<sup>2</sup><br />(290/sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;">21\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Flag_of_Romania.svg/23px-Flag_of_Romania.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" />(18,933&#160;sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="6996111000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>111/km<sup>2</sup><br />(290/sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: data-sort-value="000000002004-05-01-0000" style="white-space:nowrap">1 May 2004</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7006208090800000000\xe2\x99\xa0">2,080,908</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7010202730000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>20,273&#160;km<sup>2</sup><br />(7,827&#160;sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="6996103000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>103/km<sup>2</sup><br />(270/sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>\n</th>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>\n</td>\n<td><span style="display:none">19860101</span><span data-sort-value="000000001986-01-01-0000" style="white-space:nowrap">1 January 1986</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7007469346320000000\xe2\x99\xa0">46,934,632</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7011504030000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>504,030&#160;km<sup>2</sup><br />(194,610&#160;sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="6995930000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>93/km<sup>2</sup><br />(240/sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;">59\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1000" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>\n</th>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>\n</td>\n<td><span style="display:none">19950101</span><span data-sort-value="000000001995-01-01-0000" style="white-space:nowrap">1 January 1995</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7007102301850000000\xe2\x99\xa0">10,230,185</span>\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="7011449964000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>449,964&#160;km<sup>2</sup><br />(173,732&#160;sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span data-sort-value="6995230000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>23/km<sup>2</sup><br />(60/sq&#160;mi)\n</td>\n<td style="text-align: right;">21\n</td></tr>\n<tr class="sortbottom" style="text-align:right;">\n<th colspan="3">27 total\n</th>\n<th><span data-sort-value="7008446834579000000\xe2\x99\xa0">446,834,579</span>\n</th>\n<th><span data-sort-value="7012423326200000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>4,233,262&#160;km<sup>2</sup><br />(1,634,472&#160;sq&#160;mi)\n</th>\n<th><span data-sort-value="6996106000000000000\xe2\x99\xa0"></span>106/km<sup>2</sup><br />(270/sq&#160;mi)\n</th>\n<th>705\n</th></tr></tbody></table>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_European_Union" title="Geography of the European Union">Geography of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>The EU\'s member states cover an area of 4,233,262 square kilometres (1,634,472&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-Area.and.population.figure_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Area.and.population.figure-142">&#91;o&#93;</a></sup> The EU\'s highest peak is <a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Graian_Alps" title="Graian Alps">Graian Alps</a>, 4,810.45 metres (15,782&#160;ft) <a href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> The lowest points in the EU are <a href="/wiki/Lammefjorden" title="Lammefjorden">Lammefjorden</a>, Denmark and <a href="/wiki/Zuidplaspolder" title="Zuidplaspolder">Zuidplaspolder</a>, Netherlands, at 7&#160;m (23&#160;ft) below sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>\nThe landscape, climate, and economy of the EU are influenced by its coastline, which is 65,993 kilometres (41,006&#160;mi) long.\n</p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/270px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/405px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/540px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>65,993&#160;km (41,006&#160;mi) coastline dominates the European climate (<a href="/wiki/Natural_Park_of_Penyal_d%27Ifac" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural Park of Penyal d&#39;Ifac">Natural Park of Penyal d\'Ifac</a>, Spain)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162.66666666667px"><div style="width: 162.66666666667px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 160.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/241px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG" decoding="async" width="161" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/361px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/481px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2288" data-file-height="1712" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> is the highest peak in the EU\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 176.66666666667px"><div style="width: 176.66666666667px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 174.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/262px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/393px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/524px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1163" data-file-height="800" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> (pictured in Budapest), is the longest river in the European Union\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 202px"><div style="width: 202px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 200px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/300px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/449px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/599px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="616" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Repovesi_National_Park" title="Repovesi National Park">Repovesi National Park</a> in Finland, where there are some 187,888 lakes larger than 500 square metres (5,382&#160;sq&#160;ft)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuorgam.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nuorgam.JPG/240px-Nuorgam.JPG" decoding="async" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nuorgam.JPG/360px-Nuorgam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nuorgam.JPG/480px-Nuorgam.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="1728" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Nuorgam" title="Nuorgam">Nuorgam</a>, a village in the <a href="/wiki/Utsjoki" title="Utsjoki">Utsjoki</a> municipality, is the <a href="/wiki/Extreme_points_of_the_European_Union" title="Extreme points of the European Union">northernmost point</a> of the European Union\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Including the overseas territories of France which are located outside the continent of Europe, but which are members of the union, the EU experiences most <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification">types of climate</a> from <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">Arctic</a> (north-east Europe) to tropical (<a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>), rendering meteorological averages for the EU as a whole meaningless. The majority of the population lives in areas with a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">maritime climate</a> (North-Western Europe and Central Europe), a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (Southern Europe), or a warm summer continental or <a href="/wiki/Hemiboreal" title="Hemiboreal">hemiboreal</a> climate (Northern <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and Central Europe).<sup id="cite_ref-Humid_Continental_climate_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Humid_Continental_climate-145">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU\'s population is highly urbanised, with some 75% of inhabitants living in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban areas</a> as of 2006. Cities are largely spread out across the EU with a large grouping in and around the <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">Benelux</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Several <a href="/wiki/Special_member_state_territories_and_the_European_Union" title="Special member state territories and the European Union">overseas territories</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">dependencies</a> of various member states are also formally part of the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:left;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_European_Union" title="Politics of the European Union">Politics of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">Institutions of the European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">Legislature of the European Union</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:502px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/500px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png" decoding="async" width="500" height="354" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/750px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/1000px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1052" data-file-height="744" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Organigram of the political system with the seven institutions of the Union in blue, national / intergovernmental elements in orange</div></div></div>\n<p>The EU operates through a hybrid system of <a href="/wiki/Supranational_union" title="Supranational union">supranational</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmentalism" title="Intergovernmentalism">intergovernmental</a> decision-making,<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-148">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-149">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> and according to the principles of <a href="/wiki/Principle_of_conferral" title="Principle of conferral">conferral</a> (which says that it should act only within the limits of the competences conferred on it by the <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>) and of <a href="/wiki/Subsidiarity#European_Union_law" title="Subsidiarity">subsidiarity</a> (which says that it should act only where an objective cannot be sufficiently achieved by the member states acting alone). <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">Laws made by the EU institutions</a> are passed in a variety of forms.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> Generally speaking, they can be classified into two groups: those which come into force without the necessity for national implementation measures (regulations) and those which specifically require national implementation measures (directives).<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Constitutionally, the EU bears some resemblance to both a <a href="/wiki/Confederation" title="Confederation">confederation</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> but has not formally defined itself as either. (It does not have a formal constitution: its status is defined by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of European Union">Treaty of European Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>). It is more integrated than a traditional confederation of states because the general level of government widely employs <a href="/wiki/Qualified_majority_voting" class="mw-redirect" title="Qualified majority voting">qualified majority voting</a> in some decision-making among the member states, rather than relying exclusively on unanimity.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> It is less integrated than a federal state because it is not a state in its own right: sovereignty continues to flow \'from the bottom up\', from the several peoples of the separate member states, rather than from a single undifferentiated whole. This is reflected in the fact that the member states remain the \'masters of the Treaties\', retaining control over the allocation of competences to the Union through constitutional change (thus retaining so-called <i>Kompetenz-kompetenz</i>); in that they retain control of the use of armed force; they retain control of taxation; and in that they retain a right of unilateral withdrawal from the Union under Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. In addition, the principle of <a href="/wiki/Subsidiarity" title="Subsidiarity">subsidiarity</a> requires that only those matters that need to be determined collectively are so determined.\n</p><p>The European Union has seven principal decision-making bodies, its <a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">institutions</a>: the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Auditors" title="European Court of Auditors">European Court of Auditors</a>. Competence in scrutinising and amending legislation is shared between the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament, while executive tasks are performed by the European Commission and in a limited capacity by the European Council (not to be confused with the aforementioned Council of the European Union). The <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> is determined by the European Central Bank. The interpretation and the application of EU law and the treaties are ensured by the Court of Justice of the European Union. The EU budget is scrutinised by the European Court of Auditors. There are also a number of ancillary bodies which advise the EU or operate in a specific area.\n</p><p>EU policy is in general promulgated by <a href="/wiki/Directive_(European_Union)" title="Directive (European Union)">EU directives</a>, which are then implemented in the <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">domestic legislation</a> of its <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Regulation_(European_Union)" title="Regulation (European Union)">EU regulations</a>, which are immediately enforceable in all member states. <a href="/wiki/Lobbying#European_Union" title="Lobbying">Lobbying</a> at EU level by special interest groups is regulated to try to balance the aspirations of private initiatives with public interest decision-making process.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tnone center"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:358px;max-width:358px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="thumbimage"><a 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/NextGenerationEU_-_StrongerTogether_-_Recovery_plan_for_Europe_-_Plan_de_relance_pour_l%27Europe_-_Heerstelplan_voor_Europe_-_Berlaymont.jpg/350px-NextGenerationEU_-_StrongerTogether_-_Recovery_plan_for_Europe_-_Plan_de_relance_pour_l%27Europe_-_Heerstelplan_voor_Europe_-_Berlaymont.jpg 2x" data-file-width="12032" data-file-height="9024" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Berlaymont_building" title="Berlaymont building">Berlaymont building</a> (<b><a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a></b>)</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_building_February_2016_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg/175px-Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg/263px-Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg/350px-Europa_building_February_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="699" data-file-height="510" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Europa_building" title="Europa building">Europa building</a> (<b><a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a></b>)</div></div></div></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Institutions">Institutions</span></h3>\n<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><b><a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">Institutions of the European Union</a></b></div>\n<table style="border: none; border-collapse: separate; border-spacing: 1em 0; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; padding: 0.5em; width: 100%;">\n\n<tbody><tr style="background: #F2F2F2; text-align: center;">\n<td style="padding-top: 1em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg" class="image"><img alt="Council of the EU and European Council.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg/40px-Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="34" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg/80px-Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="280" data-file-height="240" /></a>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-top: 1em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg" class="image"><img alt="Council of the EU and European Council.svg"
