//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg/80px-Council_of_the_EU_and_European_Council.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="280" data-file-height="240" /></a>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-top: 1em;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Parliament_logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="European Parliament logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/European_Parliament_logo.svg/40px-European_Parliament_logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="28" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/European_Parliament_logo.svg/60px-European_Parliament_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/European_Parliament_logo.svg/80px-European_Parliament_logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="241" data-file-height="166" /></a>\n</td>\n<td style="padding-top: 1em;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Commission.svg" class="image"><img alt="European Commission.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/European_Commission.svg/40px-European_Commission.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="28" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/European_Commission.svg/60px-European_Commission.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/European_Commission.svg/80px-European_Commission.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="208" /></a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="background: #F2F2F2; text-align: center;">\n<th style="width: 25%"><a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>\n</th>\n<th style="width: 25%"><a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a>\n</th>\n<th style="width: 25%"><a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>\n</th>\n<th style="width: 25%"><a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>\n</th></tr>\n<tr style="background: #F2F2F2; text-align: center;">\n<td>Provides impetus and direction\n</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a>\n</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a>\n</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="background: #F2F2F2; text-align: center;">\n<td>Based in <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>\n</td>\n<td>Based in <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>\n</td>\n<td>Based in <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>, <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>\n</td>\n<td>Based in <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg/45px-Flag_of_Belgium_%28civil%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="background: #F2F2F2;">\n<td style="padding-bottom: 1em; padding-left: 1.5em; vertical-align: top;">Sets the <i>general political directions</i> and <i>priorities</i> of the Union by gathering together its member states\' <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">heads of state</a>/<a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">government</a> (elected chief executives). The conclusions of its summits (held at least quarterly) are adopted by consensus.\n</td>\n<td style="padding-bottom: 1em; padding-left: 1.5em; vertical-align: top;">Brings together ministers of member states governments\' departments. It serves to represent the various governments directly and its approval is required for any proposal to enter into law.\n</td>\n<td style="padding-bottom: 1em; padding-left: 1.5em; vertical-align: top;">Consists of 705 directly elected representatives. It shares with the Council of the EU equal legislative powers to amend, approve or reject Commission proposals for most areas of EU legislation. Its powers are limited in areas where member states\' view sovereignty to be of primary concern (i.e. defence). It elects the commission\'s president, must approve the College of Commissioners, and may vote to remove them collectively from office.\n</td>\n<td style="vertical-align: top; padding-left: 15px; padding-bottom: 10px;">The only institution empowered to propose legislation, serves as the "Guardian of the Treaties". It consists of an <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">executive cabinet</a> of public officials, led by an <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">indirectly elected</a> President. This <i>College of Commissioners</i> manages and directs the commission\'s permanent civil service. It turns the consensus objectives of the European Council into <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">legislative proposals</a>.\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Council">European Council</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:112px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charles_Michel_(49467991288).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg/110px-Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="110" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg/165px-Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg/220px-Charles_Michel_%2849467991288%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2667" data-file-height="4000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Charles_Michel_(49467991288).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Michel" title="Charles Michel">Charles Michel</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The <b>European Council</b> gives political direction to the EU. It convenes at least four times a year and comprises the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a> (<a href="/wiki/Charles_Michel" title="Charles Michel">Charles Michel</a>), the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a> and one representative per <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state</a> (either its <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> or <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>). The <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a> (<a href="/wiki/Josep_Borrell" title="Josep Borrell">Josep Borrell</a>) also takes part in its meetings. It has been described by some as the Union\'s "supreme political authority".<sup id="cite_ref-How_work_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_work-157">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> It is actively involved in the negotiation of <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaty changes</a> and defines the EU\'s policy agenda and strategies.\n</p><p>The European Council uses its leadership role to sort out disputes between member states and the institutions, and to resolve political crises and disagreements over controversial issues and policies. It acts externally as a "<a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">collective head of state</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Ratification" title="Ratification">ratifies</a> important documents (for example, international agreements and treaties).<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Tasks for the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a> are ensuring the external representation of the EU,<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Press_Release_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Press_Release-159">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> driving consensus and resolving divergences among member states, both during meetings of the European Council and over the periods between them.\n</p><p>The European Council should not be mistaken for the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, an international organisation independent of the EU based in Strasbourg.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Commission">European Commission</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:112px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ursula_von_der_Leyen_(49468709252).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg/110px-Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="110" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg/165px-Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg/220px-Ursula_von_der_Leyen_%2849468709252%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="919" data-file-height="1378" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ursula_von_der_Leyen_(49468709252).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen" title="Ursula von der Leyen">Ursula von der Leyen</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The <b>European Commission</b> acts both as the EU\'s <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive arm</a>, responsible for the day-to-day running of the EU, and also the <a href="/wiki/Right_of_initiative_(legislative)" title="Right of initiative (legislative)">legislative initiator</a>, with the sole power to propose laws for debate.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Library_of_European_Parliament_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_European_Parliament-161">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> The commission is \'guardian of the Treaties\' and is responsible for their efficient operation and policing.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> It operates <i>de facto</i> as a <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet government</a>,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> with 27 <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner" title="European Commissioner">Commissioners</a> for different areas of policy, one from each member state, though Commissioners are bound to represent the interests of the EU as a whole rather than their home state.\n</p><p>One of the 27 is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen" title="Ursula von der Leyen">Ursula von der Leyen</a> for 2019\xe2\x80\x932024), <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission#Appointment" title="President of the European Commission">appointed by the European Council</a>, subject to the Parliament\'s approval. After the President, the most prominent Commissioner is the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>, who is <i>ex-officio</i> a <a href="/wiki/Vice-President_of_the_European_Commission" title="Vice-President of the European Commission">Vice-President of the Commission</a> and is also chosen by the European Council.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> The other 26 Commissioners are subsequently appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a> in agreement with the nominated President. The 27 Commissioners as a single body are subject to approval (or otherwise) by vote of the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Council_of_the_European_Union">Council of the European Union</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>The <b>Council of the European Union</b> (also called the <b>Council</b><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> and the "Council of Ministers", its former title)<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> forms one half of the EU\'s legislature. It consists of a <a href="/wiki/Minister_(government)" title="Minister (government)">government minister</a> from each member state and meets in <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union#Configurations" title="Council of the European Union">different compositions depending on the policy area being addressed</a>. Notwithstanding its different configurations, it is considered to be one single body.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Council_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Council-167">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> In addition to its legislative functions, the council also exercises <a href="/wiki/Executive_functions" title="Executive functions">executive functions</a> in relations to the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>.\n</p><p>In some policies, there are several member states that ally with strategic partners within the Union. Examples of such alliances include the <a href="/wiki/Visegrad_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Visegrad Group">Visegrad Group</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">Benelux</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">Baltic Assembly</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_Hanseatic_League" title="New Hanseatic League">New Hanseatic League</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Triangle" title="Weimar Triangle">Weimar Triangle</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lublin_Triangle" title="Lublin Triangle">Lublin Triangle</a>, <a href="/wiki/EU_Med_Group" title="EU Med Group">EU Med Group</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Craiova_Group" title="Craiova Group">Craiova Group</a>.\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Parliament">European Parliament</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:112px;"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Sassoli_2020_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg/110px-David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="110" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg/165px-David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-David_Sassoli_2020_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="331" data-file-height="466" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Sassoli_2020_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Parliament" title="President of the European Parliament">President of the European Parliament</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Sassoli" title="David Sassoli">David Sassoli</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The <b>European Parliament</b> is one of three <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">legislative institutions</a> of the EU, which together with the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a> is tasked with amending and approving the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">Commission</a>\'s proposals.\nThe 705 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_the_European_Parliament" title="Member of the European Parliament">Members of the European Parliament</a> (MEPs) are directly <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Elections in the European Union">elected</a> by <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">EU citizens</a> every five years on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>. MEPs are elected on a national basis and they sit according to <a href="/wiki/Political_groups_of_the_European_Parliament" title="Political groups of the European Parliament">political groups</a> rather than their nationality. Each country has a set number of seats and is divided into <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament_constituency" title="European Parliament constituency">sub-national constituencies</a> where this does not affect the proportional nature of the voting system.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Ordinary_legislative_procedure" class="mw-redirect" title="Ordinary legislative procedure">ordinary legislative procedure</a>, the European Commission proposes legislation, which requires the joint approval of the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to pass. This process applies to nearly all areas, including the <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">EU budget</a>. The Parliament is the final body to approve or reject the proposed membership of the commission, and can attempt motions of censure on the commission by appeal to the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">Court of Justice</a>. The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Parliament" title="President of the European Parliament">President of the European Parliament</a> (<a href="/wiki/David_Sassoli" title="David Sassoli">David Sassoli</a>) carries out the role of speaker in Parliament and represents it externally. The President and <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_European_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Vice President of the European Parliament">Vice-Presidents</a> are elected by MEPs every two and a half years.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Parliament_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Parliament-169">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Budget">Budget</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_Programme_funding.png" class="image"><img alt="European Union 2014\xe2\x80\x932020 Multiannual Financial Framework" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/EU_Programme_funding.png/340px-EU_Programme_funding.png" decoding="async" width="340" height="448" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/EU_Programme_funding.png/510px-EU_Programme_funding.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/19/EU_Programme_funding.png 2x" data-file-width="616" data-file-height="812" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_Programme_funding.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>European Union 2014\xe2\x80\x932020 Multiannual Financial Framework<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">Budget of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>The EU had an agreed budget of \xe2\x82\xac120.7&#160;billion for the year 2007 and \xe2\x82\xac864.3&#160;billion for the period 2007\xe2\x80\x932013,<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> representing 1.10% and 1.05% of the EU-27\'s <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">GNI</a> forecast for the respective periods. In 1960, the budget of the then European Economic Community was 0.03% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the 2010 budget of \xe2\x82\xac141.5&#160;billion, the largest single expenditure item is "<i><a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Fund" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund">cohesion &amp; competitiveness</a></i>" with around 45% of the total budget.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-173">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> Next comes "<i><a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a></i>" with approximately 31% of the total.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-173">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> "<i>Rural development, environment and <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">fisheries</a></i>" takes up around 11%.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_173-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-173">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> "<i>Administration</i>" accounts for around 6%.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_173-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-173">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> The "<i>EU as a global partner</i>" and "<i>citizenship, freedom, security and justice</i>" bring up the rear with approximately 6% and 1% respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_173-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-173">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Auditors" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Auditors">Court of Auditors</a> is legally obliged to provide the Parliament and the council (specifically, the <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_Financial_Affairs_Council" title="Economic and Financial Affairs Council">Economic and Financial Affairs Council</a>) with "a statement of assurance as to the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions".<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> The Court also gives opinions and proposals on financial legislation and anti-fraud actions.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Auditors_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Auditors-175">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> The Parliament uses this to decide whether to approve the commission\'s handling of the budget.\n</p><p>The European Court of Auditors has signed off the European Union accounts every year since 2007 and, while making it clear that the European Commission has more work to do, has highlighted that most of the errors take place at national level.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Court_of_Auditors_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Court_of_Auditors-176">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-177">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> In their report on 2009 the auditors found that five areas of Union expenditure, <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Fund" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund">cohesion fund</a>, were materially affected by error.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> The European Commission estimated in 2009 that the financial effect of irregularities was \xe2\x82\xac1,863&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In November 2020, members of the Union, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, blocked approval to the EU\'s budget at a meeting in the <a href="/wiki/Committee_of_Permanent_Representatives" title="Committee of Permanent Representatives">Committee of Permanent Representatives</a> (Coreper), citing a proposal that linked funding with adherence to the rule of law. The budget included a <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">covid</a> recovery fund of \xe2\x82\xac750<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion. The budget may still be approved if Hungary and Poland withdraw their vetos after further negotiations in the Council and the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Competences">Competences</span></h3>\n<p>EU member states retain all powers not explicitly handed to the European Union. In some areas the EU enjoys exclusive competence. These are areas in which member states have renounced any capacity to enact legislation. In other areas the EU and its member states share the competence to legislate. While both can legislate, member states can only legislate to the extent to which the EU has not. In other policy areas the EU can only co-ordinate, support and supplement member state action but cannot enact legislation with the aim of harmonising national laws.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>That a particular policy area falls into a certain category of competence is not necessarily indicative of what <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">legislative procedure</a> is used for enacting legislation within that policy area. Different legislative procedures are used within the same category of competence, and even with the same policy area.\n</p><p>The distribution of competences in various policy areas between Member States and the Union is divided in the following three categories:\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<table style="width:100%;background:none;">\n<caption><b>Competences of the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">European Union</a> in relation to those of its <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a></b><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist" style="float:right;font-size:100%;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:EU_competences" class="mw-redirect" title="Template:EU competences"><span title="View this template">view</span></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:EU_competences" class="mw-redirect" title="Template talk:EU competences"><span title="Discuss this template">talk</span></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:EU_competences&amp;action=edit"><span title="Edit this template">edit</span></a></li></ul></div>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top;">\n<td style="width:25%;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2">\n\n<tbody><tr style="text-align:center;">\n<td style="width:25%;border:1px solid #9db0f6;background:#becdf1; padding:5px; font-weight:bold">Exclusive competence\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td>\n<td colspan="2" style="width:50%;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2">\n\n<tbody><tr style="text-align:center;">\n<td style="width:50%;border:1px solid #bac6f4;background:#d7dff4;padding:5px; font-weight:bold">Shared competence\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td>\n<td style="width:25%;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2">\n\n<tbody><tr style="text-align:center;">\n<td style="width:25%;border:1px solid #e6ecfd;background:#f3f5fd;padding:5px; font-weight:bold">Supporting competence\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td></tr>\n\n\n<tr>\n<td style="vertical-align:top;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" style="padding-top:5px;">\n\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:90%;text-align:center;">\n<td style="background:#9db0f6;padding:5px;line-height:1.2em;border-bottom:2px dotted white;"><i>The Union has exclusive competence to make directives and conclude international agreements when provided for in a Union legislative act as to \xe2\x80\xa6</i>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:90%;vertical-align:top;text-align:left;">\n<td style="background:#9db0f6;padding-bottom:5px;">\n<div><ul><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">customs union</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the establishing of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">competition rules</a> necessary for the functioning of the internal market</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">monetary policy for the Member States whose currency is the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the conservation of marine biological resources under the <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">common fisheries policy</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/EU_Common_Commercial_Policy" class="mw-redirect" title="EU Common Commercial Policy">Common Commercial Policy</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">conclusion of certain <a href="/wiki/International_agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="International agreement">international agreements</a></li></ul></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td>\n<td style="width:25%;vertical-align:top;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" style="padding-top:5px;">\n\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:90%;text-align:center;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding:5px;line-height:1.2em;border-bottom:2px dotted white;"><i>Member States cannot exercise competence in areas where the Union has done so, that is \xe2\x80\xa6</i>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:90%;vertical-align:top;text-align:left;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding-bottom:5px;">\n<div><ul><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">internal market</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">social policy, for the aspects defined in this Treaty</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">economic, social and territorial cohesion</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">fisheries</a>, excluding the conservation of marine biological resources</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Environment_in_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Environment in the European Union">environment</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">consumer protection</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Transport_in_the_European_Union" title="Transport in the European Union">transport</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Trans-European_Networks" title="Trans-European Networks">trans-European networks</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Energy policy of the European Union">energy</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the <a href="/wiki/Area_of_freedom,_security_and_justice" title="Area of freedom, security and justice">area of freedom, security and justice</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">common safety concerns in public health matters, for the aspects defined in this Treaty</li></ul></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td>\n<td style="width:25%;vertical-align:top;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" style="padding-top:5px;">\n\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:90%;text-align:center;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding:5px;line-height:1.2em;border-bottom:2px dotted white;"><i>Union exercise of competence shall not result in Member States being prevented from exercising theirs in \xe2\x80\xa6</i>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:90%;vertical-align:top;text-align:left;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding-bottom:5px;border-bottom:4px solid white;">\n<div><ul><li style="line-height:1.2em;">research, technological development and&#160;<a href="/wiki/European_Space_Policy" class="mw-redirect" title="European Space Policy">(outer) space</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">development cooperation, humanitarian aid</li></ul></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2">\n\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:90%;text-align:center;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding:5px;line-height:1.2em;border-bottom:2px dotted white;"><i>The Union coordinates Member States policies or implements supplemental to their common policies not covered elsewhere in \xe2\x80\xa6</i>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:90%;vertical-align:top;text-align:left;">\n<td style="background:#bac6f4;padding-bottom:5px;">\n<div><ul><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the coordination of economic, employment and social policies</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">common <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">foreign, security</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">defence</a> policies</li></ul></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td>\n<td style="width:25%;vertical-align:top;">\n<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" style="padding-top:5px;">\n\n<tbody><tr style="font-size:90%;text-align:center;">\n<td style="background:#e6ecfd;padding:5px;line-height:1.2em;border-bottom:2px dotted white;"><i>The Union can carry out actions to support, coordinate or supplement Member States\' actions in \xe2\x80\xa6</i>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:90%;vertical-align:top;text-align:left;">\n<td style="background:#e6ecfd;padding-bottom:5px;">\n<div><ul><li style="line-height:1.2em;">the protection and improvement of human health</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">industry</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Cultural_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Cultural policies of the European Union">culture</a></li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">tourism</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Educational_policies_and_initiatives_of_the_European_Union" title="Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union">education</a>, youth, <a href="/wiki/Sport_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Sport policies of the European Union">sport</a> and vocational training</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">civil protection (disaster prevention)</li><li style="line-height:1.2em;">administrative cooperation</li></ul></div>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system_and_justice">Legal system and justice</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">European Union law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">Treaties of the European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>The EU is based on a series of <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>. These first established the European Community and the EU, and then made amendments to those founding treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> These are power-giving treaties which set broad policy goals and establish institutions with the necessary legal powers to implement those goals. These legal powers include the ability to enact legislation<sup id="cite_ref-art249_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art249-185">&#91;p&#93;</a></sup> which can directly affect all member states and their inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-Direct_Effect_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Direct_Effect-186">&#91;q&#93;</a></sup> The EU has <a href="/wiki/Legal_personality" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal personality">legal personality</a>, with the right to sign agreements and international treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Under the principle of <a href="/wiki/Supremacy_(European_Union_law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Supremacy (European Union law)">supremacy</a>, national courts are required to enforce the treaties that their member states have ratified, and thus the laws enacted under them, even if doing so requires them to ignore conflicting national law, and (within limits) even constitutional provisions.<sup id="cite_ref-Supremacy_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Supremacy-188">&#91;r&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> and supremacy doctrines were not explicitly set out in the European Treaties but were developed by the Court of Justice itself over the 1960s, apparently under the influence of its then most influential judge, Frenchman <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lecourt" title="Robert Lecourt">Robert Lecourt</a><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_(CJEU)_after_fifth_extension,_January_2020.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg/220px-Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg/330px-Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg/440px-Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_%28CJEU%29_after_fifth_extension%2C_January_2020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5514" data-file-height="3676" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Towers_of_the_Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union_(CJEU)_after_fifth_extension,_January_2020.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The towers of the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a>, seated in <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg_City" title="Luxembourg City">Luxembourg City</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial branch</a> of the EU\xe2\x80\x94formally called the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a>\xe2\x80\x94consists of two courts: the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">Court of Justice</a> and the <a href="/wiki/General_Court_(European_Union)" title="General Court (European Union)">General Court</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>\nThe Court of Justice primarily deals with cases taken by member states, the institutions, and <a href="/wiki/Preliminary_ruling" title="Preliminary ruling">cases referred to it</a> by the courts of member states.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> Because of the doctrines of <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> and supremacy, many judgments of the Court of Justice are automatically applicable within the internal legal orders of the member states.\n</p><p>The General Court mainly deals with cases taken by individuals and companies directly before the EU\'s courts,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> and the European Union Civil Service Tribunal adjudicates in disputes between the European Union and <a href="/wiki/European_Civil_Service" title="European Civil Service">its civil service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> Decisions from the General Court can be appealed to the Court of Justice but only on a point of law.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fundamental_rights">Fundamental rights</span></h3>\n<p>The treaties declare that the EU itself is "founded on the values of respect for <a href="/wiki/Human_dignity" class="mw-redirect" title="Human dignity">human dignity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberty" title="Liberty">freedom</a>, democracy, <a href="/wiki/Equality_before_the_law" title="Equality before the law">equality</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a> and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">minorities</a>&#160;... in a society in which pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail."<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisbon Treaty">Lisbon Treaty</a> gave legal effect to the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a>. The charter is a codified catalogue of <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_right" class="mw-redirect" title="Fundamental right">fundamental rights</a> against which the EU\'s legal acts can be judged. It consolidates many rights which were previously recognised by the Court of Justice and derived from the "constitutional traditions common to the member states."<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> The Court of Justice has long recognised fundamental rights and has, on occasion, invalidated EU legislation based on its failure to adhere to those fundamental rights.<sup id="cite_ref-europarl-rights_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europarl-rights-197">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/220px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="258" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/330px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/440px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1741" data-file-height="2044" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci" class="mw-redirect" title="Parada R\xc3\xb3wno\xc5\x9bci">Warsaw Pride</a> 2018. Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights asserts that "any discrimination based on any ground such as [...] sexual orientation shall be prohibited."</div></div></div>\n<p>Signing the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a> (ECHR) is a condition for EU membership.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;s&#93;</a></sup> Previously, the EU itself could not accede to the convention as it is neither a state<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;t&#93;</a></sup> nor had the competence to accede.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;u&#93;</a></sup> The Lisbon Treaty and Protocol 14 to the ECHR have changed this: the former binds the EU to accede to the convention while the latter formally permits it.\n</p><p>The EU is independent from the Council of Europe, although they share purpose and ideas,  especially on the rule of law, human rights and democracy. Furthermore, the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Social_Charter" title="European Social Charter">European Social Charter</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Source_of_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Source of law">source of law</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights</a> are created by the Council of Europe. The EU has also promoted human rights issues in the wider world. The EU opposes the death penalty and has proposed its worldwide abolition. Abolition of the death penalty is a condition for EU membership.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 19 October 2020, the European Union revealed new plans to create a legal structure to act against human rights violations worldwide. The new plan was expected to provide the European Union with greater flexibility to target and sanction those responsible for serious <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_violations" class="mw-redirect" title="Human rights violations">human rights violations</a> and abuses around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Acts">Acts</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/European_Citizens%27_Initiative" title="European Citizens&#39; Initiative">European Citizens\' Initiative</a></div>\n<p>The main legal acts of the EU come in three forms: <a href="/wiki/Regulation_(European_Union)" title="Regulation (European Union)">regulations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Directive_(European_Union)" title="Directive (European Union)">directives</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Decision_(European_Union)" title="Decision (European Union)">decisions</a>. Regulations become law in all member states the moment they come into force, without the requirement for any implementing measures,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;v&#93;</a></sup> and automatically override conflicting domestic provisions.<sup id="cite_ref-art249_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art249-185">&#91;p&#93;</a></sup> Directives require member states to achieve a certain result while leaving them discretion as to how to achieve the result. The details of how they are to be implemented are left to member states.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;w&#93;</a></sup> When the time limit for implementing directives passes, they may, under certain conditions, have <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> in national law against member states.\n</p><p>Decisions offer an alternative to the two above modes of legislation. They are legal acts which only apply to specified individuals, companies or a particular member state. They are most often used in <a href="/wiki/Competition_law" title="Competition law">competition law</a>, or on rulings on State Aid, but are also frequently used for procedural or administrative matters within the institutions. Regulations, directives, and decisions are of equal legal value and apply without any formal hierarchy.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Ombudsman">European Ombudsman</span></h3>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Ombudsman" title="European Ombudsman">European Ombudsman</a> was established by the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ombudsman" title="Ombudsman">ombudsman</a> is elected by the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> for the length of the Parliament\'s term, and the position is renewable.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> Any EU citizen or entity may appeal to the ombudsman to investigate an EU institution on the grounds of maladministration (administrative irregularities, unfairness, discrimination, abuse of power, failure to reply, refusal of information or unnecessary delay).<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Emily_O%27Reilly" title="Emily O&#39;Reilly">Emily O\'Reilly</a> is the ombudsman since 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Home_affairs_and_migration">Home affairs and migration</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Area_of_freedom,_security_and_justice" title="Area of freedom, security and justice">Area of freedom, security and justice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">Citizenship of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>Since the creation of the EU in 1993, it has developed its competencies in the area of justice and home affairs; initially at an intergovernmental level and later by supranationalism. Accordingly, the Union has legislated in areas such as <a href="/wiki/European_Arrest_Warrant" title="European Arrest Warrant">extradition</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> family law,<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> asylum law,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> and criminal justice.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> Prohibitions against sexual and nationality discrimination have a long standing in the treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-art39/141_Rome_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art39/141_Rome-213">&#91;x&#93;</a></sup> In more recent years, these have been supplemented by powers to legislate against discrimination based on race, religion, disability, age, and sexual orientation.<sup id="cite_ref-art2(7)_Amsterdam_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art2(7)_Amsterdam-214">&#91;y&#93;</a></sup> By virtue of these powers, the EU has enacted legislation on <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexual discrimination</a> in the work-place, <a href="/wiki/Ageism" title="Ageism">age discrimination</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racial discrimination</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;z&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Union has also established agencies to co-ordinate police, prosecutorial and immigrations controls across the member states: <a href="/wiki/Europol" title="Europol">Europol</a> for co-operation of police forces,<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eurojust" title="Eurojust">Eurojust</a> for co-operation between prosecutors,<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> for co-operation between border control authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> The EU also operates the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Information_System" title="Schengen Information System">Schengen Information System</a><sup id="cite_ref-Internal_borders_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Internal_borders-18">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> which provides a common database for police and immigration authorities. This co-operation had to particularly be developed with the advent of open borders through the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> and the associated cross border crime.\n</p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>Seat of <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> in Warsaw, Poland\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n</ul>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_European_Union" title="Foreign relations of the European Union">Foreign relations of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_External_Action_Service" title="European External Action Service">European External Action Service</a></div>\n<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:602px;"><div class="noresize"><map
