alt="Monaco" title="Monaco" /><area href="/wiki/Andorra" shape="rect" coords="325,376,356,404" alt="Andorra" title="Andorra" /><area href="/wiki/San_Marino" shape="rect" coords="361,376,391,404" alt="San Marino" title="San Marino" /><area href="/wiki/Vatican_City" shape="rect" coords="550,376,580,404" alt="Vatican City" title="Vatican City" /><area href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" shape="rect" coords="436,58,467,86" alt="Georgia" title="Georgia" /><area href="/wiki/Ukraine" shape="rect" coords="419,86,449,113" alt="Ukraine" title="Ukraine" /><area href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" shape="rect" coords="454,86,484,113" alt="Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan" /><area href="/wiki/Moldova" shape="rect" coords="436,119,467,146" alt="Moldova" title="Moldova" /><area href="/wiki/Armenia" shape="rect" coords="502,86,532,113" alt="Armenia" title="Armenia" /><area href="/wiki/Russia" shape="rect" coords="502,53,532,81" alt="Russia" title="Russia" /><area href="/wiki/Belarus" shape="rect" coords="550,53,580,81" alt="Belarus" title="Belarus" /><area href="/wiki/Serbia" shape="rect" coords="502,119,532,146" alt="Serbia" title="Serbia" /><area href="/wiki/Albania" shape="rect" coords="502,146,532,174" alt="Albania" title="Albania" /><area href="/wiki/Montenegro" shape="rect" coords="502,179,532,207" alt="Montenegro" title="Montenegro" /><area href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" shape="rect" coords="464,179,494,207" alt="North Macedonia" title="North Macedonia" /><area href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" shape="rect" coords="426,179,457,207" alt="Bosnia and Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina" /><area href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Administration_Mission_in_Kosovo" shape="rect" coords="555,146,585,174" alt="Kosovo (UNMIK)" title="Kosovo (UNMIK)" /></map><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg/600px-Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="600" height="424" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg/900px-Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg/1200px-Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1189" data-file-height="841" usemap="#ImageMap_14cb173ea6fb4fed" /></div>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Supranational_European_Bodies-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A clickable <a href="/wiki/Euler_diagram" title="Euler diagram">Euler diagram</a> showing the relationships between various multinational European organisations and agreements.<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float:right"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Supranational_European_Bodies" title="Template:Supranational European Bodies"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Supranational_European_Bodies" title="Template talk:Supranational European Bodies"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Supranational_European_Bodies&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg/220px-Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg/330px-Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg/440px-Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3506" data-file-height="2337" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Family_photo_of_the_2019_G20_Osaka_summit.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The EU participates in all <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">G7</a> and <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a> summits. (<a href="/wiki/2019_G20_Osaka_summit" title="2019 G20 Osaka summit">G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, 2019</a>).</div></div></div>\n<p>Foreign policy co-operation between member states dates from the establishment of the Community in 1957, when member states negotiated as a bloc in international trade negotiations under the <a href="/wiki/EU%27s_common_commercial_policy" class="mw-redirect" title="EU&#39;s common commercial policy">EU\'s common commercial policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> Steps for a more wide-ranging co-ordination in foreign relations began in 1970 with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/European_Political_Cooperation" class="mw-redirect" title="European Political Cooperation">European Political Cooperation</a> which created an informal consultation process between member states with the aim of forming common foreign policies. In 1987 the European Political Cooperation was introduced on a formal basis by the <a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a>. EPC was renamed as the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a> (CFSP) by the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EPC_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EPC-220">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The aims of the CFSP are to promote both the EU\'s own interests and those of the <a href="/wiki/International_community" title="International community">international community</a> as a whole, including the furtherance of international co-operation, respect for human rights, democracy, and the rule of law.<sup id="cite_ref-art11_Union_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art11_Union-221">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The CFSP requires unanimity among the member states on the appropriate policy to follow on any particular issue. The unanimity and difficult issues treated under the CFSP sometimes lead to disagreements, such as those which occurred over the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">war in Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Iraq_statement_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Iraq_statement-222">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Josep_Borrell_(49468484246).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg/150px-Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg/225px-Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg/300px-Josep_Borrell_%2849468484246%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2183" data-file-height="3280" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Josep_Borrell_(49468484246).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Josep_Borrell" title="Josep Borrell">Josep Borrell</a>, <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The coordinator and representative of the CFSP within the EU is the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a> who speaks on behalf of the EU in foreign policy and defence matters, and has the task of articulating the positions expressed by the member states on these fields of policy into a common alignment. The High Representative heads up the <a href="/wiki/European_External_Action_Service" title="European External Action Service">European External Action Service</a> (EEAS), a unique EU department<sup id="cite_ref-23Oct_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23Oct-223">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> that has been officially implemented and operational since 1 December 2010 on the occasion of the first anniversary of the entry into force of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> The EEAS will serve as a foreign ministry and <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_corps" title="Diplomatic corps">diplomatic corps</a> for the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_EEAS_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_EEAS-225">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Besides the emerging international policy of the European Union, the international influence of the EU is also felt through <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">enlargement</a>. The perceived benefits of becoming a member of the EU act as an incentive for both political and economic reform in states wishing to fulfil the EU\'s accession criteria, and are considered an important factor contributing to the reform of European formerly Communist countries.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>762</span></sup> This influence on the internal affairs of other countries is generally referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Soft_power" title="Soft power">soft power</a>", as opposed to military "hard power".<sup id="cite_ref-Soft_Power_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soft_Power-227">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> was called to vote on whether to end the agreement with European Union on the free movement of people, in September 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> The demand of <a href="/wiki/Swiss_People%27s_Party" title="Swiss People&#39;s Party">Swiss People\'s Party</a> (SPP) was, however, turned down, as the voters rejected SPP\'s demand for taking back immigration control.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Security_and_defence">Security and defence</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">Common Security and Defence Policy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Plus_agreement" title="Berlin Plus agreement">Berlin Plus agreement</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_NATO.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/EU_and_NATO.svg/220px-EU_and_NATO.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/EU_and_NATO.svg/330px-EU_and_NATO.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/EU_and_NATO.svg/440px-EU_and_NATO.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="520" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_NATO.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Out of the 27 EU member states, 21 are also members of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. Another four NATO members are EU applicants \xe2\x80\x93 Albania, Montenegro, Turkey and North Macedonia.</div></div></div>\n<p>The predecessors of the European Union were not devised as a military alliance because <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> was largely seen as appropriate and sufficient for defence purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilkinson2007100_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilkinson2007100-230">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> 21 EU members are members of NATO<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> while the remaining member states follow policies of <a href="/wiki/Neutrality_(international_relations)" class="mw-redirect" title="Neutrality (international relations)">neutrality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a>, a military alliance with a mutual defence clause, was disbanded in 2010 as its role had been transferred to the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since the withdrawal of the United Kingdom, France is the only member officially recognised as a <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapon state</a> and the sole holder of a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent seat</a> on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>. Possessing the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">EU\'s largest armed forces</a> and the largest national defence budget of the bloc,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> France is also the only EU country that has <a href="/wiki/Power_projection" title="Power projection">power projection capabilities</a> outside of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Most EU member states opposed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Nuclear Weapon Ban Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a> in 1999, the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a> agreed that "the Union must have the capacity for autonomous action, backed by credible military forces, the means to decide to use them, and the readiness to do so, in order to respond to international crises without prejudice to actions by NATO". To that end, a number of efforts were made to increase the EU\'s military capability, notably the <a href="/wiki/Helsinki_Headline_Goal" title="Helsinki Headline Goal">Helsinki Headline Goal</a> process. After much discussion, the most concrete result was the <a href="/wiki/EU_Battlegroup" title="EU Battlegroup">EU Battlegroups</a> initiative, each of which is planned to be able to deploy quickly about 1500&#160;personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Capabilities_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Capabilities-237">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/EUFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="EUFOR">EU forces</a> have been deployed on peacekeeping missions from middle and northern Africa to the <a href="/wiki/Western_Balkans" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Balkans">western Balkans</a> and western Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Operations_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Operations-238">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> EU military operations are supported by a number of bodies, including the <a href="/wiki/European_Defence_Agency" title="European Defence Agency">European Defence Agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Satellite_Centre" title="European Union Satellite Centre">European Union Satellite Centre</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Military_Staff" title="European Union Military Staff">European Union Military Staff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Structures_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Structures-239">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Agencies_of_the_European_Union" title="Agencies of the European Union">agency of the EU</a> established to manage the cooperation between national <a href="/wiki/Border_guard" title="Border guard">border guards</a> securing its external <a href="/wiki/Border" title="Border">borders</a>. It aims to detect and stop illegal immigration, <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking">human trafficking</a> and terrorist infiltration. In 2015 the European Commission presented its proposal for a new European Border and Coast Guard Agency having a stronger role and mandate along with national authorities for border management. In an EU consisting of 27 members, substantial security and defence co-operation is increasingly relying on collaboration among all member states.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Humanitarian_aid">Humanitarian aid</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_European_Civil_Protection_and_Humanitarian_Aid_Operations" title="Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations">Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/ECHO_(European_Commission)" class="mw-redirect" title="ECHO (European Commission)">European Commission\'s Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection department</a>, or "ECHO", provides <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_aid" title="Humanitarian aid">humanitarian aid</a> from the EU to <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing countries</a>. In 2012, its budget amounted to \xe2\x82\xac874<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million, 51% of the budget went to Africa and 20% to Asia, Latin America, the Caribbean and Pacific, and 20% to the Middle East and Mediterranean.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Humanitarian aid is financed directly by the budget (70%) as part of the financial instruments for external action and also by the <a href="/wiki/European_Development_Fund" title="European Development Fund">European Development Fund</a> (30%).<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-242">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> The EU\'s external action financing is divided into \'geographic\' instruments and \'thematic\' instruments.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-242">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> The \'geographic\' instruments provide aid through the <a href="/wiki/Development_Cooperation_Instrument" title="Development Cooperation Instrument">Development Cooperation Instrument</a> (DCI, \xe2\x82\xac16.9<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion, 2007\xe2\x80\x932013), which must spend 95% of its budget on <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> (ODA), and from the <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_and_Partnership_Instrument" class="mw-redirect" title="European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument">European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument</a> (ENPI), which contains some relevant programmes.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_242-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-242">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> The European Development Fund (EDF, \xe2\x82\xac22.7<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion for the period 2008\xe2\x80\x932013 and \xe2\x82\xac30.5<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>billion for the period 2014\xe2\x80\x932020) is made up of voluntary contributions by member states, but there is pressure to merge the EDF into the budget-financed instruments to encourage increased contributions to match the 0.7% target and allow the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> greater oversight.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_242-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-242">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2016, the average among EU countries was 0.4% and five had met or exceeded the 0.7% target: Denmark, Germany, Luxembourg, Sweden and the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> If considered collectively, EU member states are the largest contributor of <a href="/wiki/List_of_development_aid_country_donors" title="List of development aid country donors">foreign aid</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-GHA_report_2014_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GHA_report_2014-245">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD_aid_report_2013_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_aid_report_2013-246">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_cooperation_and_development_partnerships">International cooperation and development partnerships</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_International_Cooperation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development">Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development</a>, <a href="/wiki/ACP%E2%80%93EU_development_cooperation" title="ACP\xe2\x80\x93EU development cooperation">ACP\xe2\x80\x93EU development cooperation</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Development_Fund" title="European Development Fund">European Development Fund</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg/220px-Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg/330px-Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg/440px-Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1335" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Eastern-Partnership-Summit-22-05-2015-2767.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Eastern Partnership Summit 2015, Riga.</div></div></div>\n<p>The EU uses foreign relations instruments like the <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a> which seeks to tie those countries to the east and south of the European territory of the EU to the Union. These countries, primarily developing countries, include some who seek to one day become either a <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a>, or more closely integrated with the European Union. The EU offers financial assistance to countries within the European Neighbourhood, so long as they meet the strict conditions of government reform, economic reform and other issues surrounding positive transformation. This process is normally underpinned by an Action Plan, as agreed by both Brussels and the target country.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Membreupm.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Membreupm.png/220px-Membreupm.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Membreupm.png/330px-Membreupm.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/20/Membreupm.png 2x" data-file-width="411" data-file-height="211" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Membreupm.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a> meeting in Barcelona.</div></div></div>\n<p>International recognition of sustainable development as a key element is growing steadily. Its role was recognized in three major UN summits on sustainable development: the 1992 <a href="/wiki/Earth_Summit" title="Earth Summit">UN Conference on Environment and Development</a> (UNCED) in Rio de Janeiro, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>; the 2002 World Summit on Sustainable Development (WSSD) in Johannesburg, <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>; and the 2012 <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Sustainable_Development" title="United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development">UN Conference on Sustainable Development</a> (UNCSD) in Rio de Janeiro. Other key global agreements are the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_Development_Goals" title="Sustainable Development Goals">2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development</a> (United Nations, 2015). The SDGs recognize that all countries must stimulate action in the following key areas \xe2\x80\x93 people, <a href="/wiki/Planet" title="Planet">planet</a>, prosperity, <a href="/wiki/Peace" title="Peace">peace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partnership" title="Partnership">partnership</a> \xe2\x80\x93 in order to tackle the global challenges that are crucial for the survival of <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humanity</a>.\n</p><p>EU development action is based on the European Consensus on Development, which was endorsed on 20 December 2005 by EU Member States, the council, the European Parliament and the commission.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> It is applied from the principles of <a href="/wiki/Capability_approach" title="Capability approach">Capability approach</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rights-based_approach_to_development" title="Rights-based approach to development">Rights-based approach to development</a>.\n</p><p>Partnership and cooperation agreements are bilateral agreements with non-member nations.<sup id="cite_ref-pca_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pca-248">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable floatcenter" style="text-align:center;">\n<caption>Partnership and Cooperation Agreements<span class="anchor" id="List_of_PCAs"></span>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>Non-EU Member state\n</th>\n<th>PCA Name\n</th>\n<th>Date Signed\n</th>\n<th>Agreement Supersedes (if any)\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>\n</td>\n<td>EU-Armenia Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement<sup id="cite_ref-armenia-cepa_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-armenia-cepa-249">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td>2018\n</td>\n<td>EU-Armenia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement,<sup id="cite_ref-armeniapca_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-armeniapca-250">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> 1999\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyrgyz Republic">Kyrgyz Republic</a>\n</td>\n<td>EU and Kyrgyz Republic Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreement<sup id="cite_ref-kyrgyz-ecpa_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kyrgyz-ecpa-251">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td>2019\n</td>\n<td>\xe2\x80\x93\n</td></tr>\n\n\n</tbody></table>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">Trade</span></h3>\n<p>The European Union is the largest exporter in the world<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> and as of 2008 the largest importer of goods and services.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> Internal trade between the member states is aided by the removal of barriers to trade such as <a href="/wiki/Tariff" title="Tariff">tariffs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Border_control" title="Border control">border controls</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, trade is helped by not having any currency differences to deal with amongst most members.<sup id="cite_ref-Se-jeong_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Se-jeong-255">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Association_Agreement" title="European Union Association Agreement">European Union Association Agreement</a> does something similar for a much larger range of countries, partly as a so-called soft approach (\'a carrot instead of a stick\') to influence the politics in those countries.\nThe European Union represents all its members at the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), and acts on behalf of member states in any disputes. When the EU negotiates trade related agreement outside the WTO framework, the subsequent agreement must be approved by each individual EU member state government.<sup id="cite_ref-Se-jeong_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Se-jeong-255">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The European Union has concluded <a href="/wiki/European_Union_free_trade_agreements" title="European Union free trade agreements">free trade agreements</a> (FTAs)<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> and other agreements with a trade component with many countries worldwide and is negotiating with many others.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union" title="Economy of the European Union">Economy of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>As a political entity the European Union is represented in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO). EU member states own the estimated second largest after the United States (<span style="white-space: nowrap">US$105</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion) <a href="/wiki/Net_wealth" class="mw-redirect" title="Net wealth">net wealth</a> in the world, equal to around 20% (~\xe2\x82\xac60<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion) of the <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$360</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion (~\xe2\x82\xac300<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>trillion)<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> global wealth.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>19 member states have joined a monetary union known as the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, which uses the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> as a single currency. The currency union represents 342<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million EU citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market-260">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> The euro is the second largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> as well as the second most traded currency in the world after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">United States dollar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Of the top <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">500 largest corporations in the world measured by revenue</a> in 2010, 161 had their headquarters in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> In 2016, unemployment in the EU stood at 8.9%<sup id="cite_ref-UNEMP_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNEMP-265">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> while inflation was at 2.2%, and the account balance at \xe2\x88\x920.9% of GDP. The average annual net earnings in the European Union was around \xe2\x82\xac24,000 (<span style="white-space: nowrap">US$30,000</span>)<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> in 2015.\n</p><p>There is a significant variation in Nominal GDP per capita within individual EU states. The difference between the richest and poorest regions (281 NUTS-2 regions of the <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics</a>) ranged, in 2017, from 31% (Severozapaden, Bulgaria) of the EU28 average (\xe2\x82\xac30,000) to 253% (Luxembourg), or from \xe2\x82\xac4,600 to \xe2\x82\xac92,600.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internal_market">Internal market</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a>, <a href="/wiki/Digital_Single_Market" title="Digital Single Market">Digital Single Market</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_consumer_law" title="European consumer law">European consumer law</a></div>\n<p>Two of the original core objectives of the European Economic Community were the development of a common market, subsequently becoming a <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">single market</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">customs union</a> between its member states. The single market involves <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">the free circulation of goods, capital, people, and services within the EU</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market-260">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> and the customs union involves the application of a <a href="/wiki/Common_external_tariff" title="Common external tariff">common external tariff</a> on all goods entering the market. Once goods have been admitted into the market they cannot be subjected to customs duties, discriminatory taxes or <a href="/wiki/Import_quota" title="Import quota">import quotas</a>, as they travel internally. The non-EU member states of <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> participate in the single market but not in the customs union.<sup id="cite_ref-EEA_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EEA-138">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> Half the trade in the EU is covered by legislation harmonised by the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_G_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_G-268">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Free movement of capital is intended to permit movement of investments such as property purchases and buying of shares between countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_C_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_C-269">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> Until the drive towards <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_monetary_union" title="Economic and monetary union">economic and monetary union</a> the development of the capital provisions had been slow. Post-Maastricht there has been a rapidly developing corpus of ECJ judgements regarding this initially neglected freedom. The free movement of capital is unique insofar as it is granted equally to non-member states.\n</p><p>The free movement of persons means that <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">EU citizens</a> can move freely between member states to live, work, study or retire in another country. This required the lowering of administrative formalities and recognition of professional qualifications of other states.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_P_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_P-270">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The free movement of services and of establishment allows self-employed persons to move between member states to provide services on a temporary or permanent basis. While services account for 60\xe2\x80\x9370% of GDP, legislation in the area is not as developed as in other areas. This lacuna has been addressed by the recently passed <a href="/wiki/Directive_on_services_in_the_internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Directive on services in the internal market">Directive on services in the internal market</a> which aims to liberalise the cross border provision of services.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_S_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_S-271">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> According to the Treaty the provision of services is a residual freedom that only applies if no other freedom is being exercised.\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1021810730">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{width:100%!important}}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{display:table}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-default{background:transparent;margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-center{margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-left{float:left}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-right{float:right}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-none{float:none}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-collapsible{width:100%}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .whitebg .thumb{background:#fff!important}</style><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="title"><div>European Union documents</div></div><div from 2 August 2021. (German version pictured)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:47px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Croatian_driving_licence.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/180px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="116" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/270px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/360px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="322" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>A <a href="/wiki/European_driving_licence" title="European driving licence">European driving licence card</a> (Croatian version pictured)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eirepas.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/128px-Eirepas.JPG" decoding="async" width="128" height="180" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/192px-Eirepas.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/256px-Eirepas.JPG 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="842" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>A <a href="/wiki/Passports_of_the_European_Union" title="Passports of the European Union">European passport</a>, displaying the name of the member state, the national <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms" title="Coat of arms">arms</a> and the words "European Union" given in their official language(s). (Irish version pictured)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:85px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:SK-number-plate-2004.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/180px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/270px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/360px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1748" data-file-height="389" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>A <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Europe" title="Vehicle registration plates of Europe">European vehicle registration plate</a>, consisting of a blue strip on the left side with the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">EU flag</a> symbol, along with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_international_license_plate_codes" class="mw-redirect" title="List of international license plate codes">country code</a> of the member state in which the vehicle is registered. (Slovak version pictured)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n</ul></div></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monetary_union_and_financial_services">Monetary union and financial services</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_Monetary_Union_of_the_European_Union" title="Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union">Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banking_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Banking Union">Banking Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Euro_Stoxx_50" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro Stoxx 50">Euro Stoxx 50</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eurobond_(eurozone)" title="Eurobond (eurozone)">Eurobond (eurozone)</a></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:120px;max-width:120px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:177px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg/118px-European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg" decoding="async" width="118" height="178" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg/177px-European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg/236px-European_Central_Bank_Frankfurt_am_Main_IMG_0164.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3090" data-file-height="4656" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:168px;max-width:168px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:177px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/166px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" decoding="async" width="166" height="178" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/249px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/332px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="645" data-file-height="690" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Left: The <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="Seat of the European Central Bank">seat of the European Central Bank</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ostend_(Frankfurt_am_Main)" title="Ostend (Frankfurt am Main)">Ostend</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>. Right: 19 of the 27 EU member states have adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> as their <a href="/wiki/Legal_tender" title="Legal tender">legal tender</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> (dark blue) represents 340&#160;million people.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>The creation of a <a href="/wiki/European_Currency_Unit" title="European Currency Unit">European single currency</a> became an official objective of the European Economic Community in 1969. In 1992, having negotiated the structure and procedures of a currency union, the member states signed the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> and were legally bound to fulfil the agreed-on rules including the <a href="/wiki/Euro_convergence_criteria" title="Euro convergence criteria">convergence criteria</a> if they wanted to join the <a href="/wiki/Currency_union" title="Currency union">monetary union</a>. The states wanting to participate had first to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Exchange_Rate_Mechanism" title="European Exchange Rate Mechanism">European Exchange Rate Mechanism</a>.\n</p><p>In 1999, the currency union started, first as an accounting currency with <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_euro" title="History of the euro">eleven member states</a> joining. In 2002, the currency was fully put into place, when <a href="/wiki/Euro_banknotes" title="Euro banknotes">euro notes</a> and coins were issued and national currencies began to phase out in the eurozone, which by then consisted of 12 member states. The eurozone (constituted by the EU member states which have adopted the euro) has since grown to 19 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;aa&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Christine_Lagarde_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="237" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Christine_Lagarde_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="843" data-file-height="1174" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Christine_Lagarde_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christine_Lagarde" title="Christine Lagarde">Christine Lagarde</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="President of the European Central Bank">President of the European Central Bank</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The euro, and the monetary policies of those who have adopted it in agreement with the EU, are under the control of the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> (ECB).<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The ECB is the central bank for the eurozone, and thus controls <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> in that area with an agenda to maintain <a href="/wiki/Price_stability" title="Price stability">price stability</a>. It is at the centre of the <a href="/wiki/European_System_of_Central_Banks" title="European System of Central Banks">European System of Central Banks</a>, which comprehends all EU national central banks and is controlled by its General Council, consisting of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="President of the European Central Bank">President of the ECB</a>, who is appointed by the European Council, the Vice-President of the ECB, and the governors of the national central banks of all 27 EU member states.<sup id="cite_ref-ECB_org_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECB_org-275">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_System_of_Financial_Supervision" title="European System of Financial Supervision">European System of Financial Supervision</a> is an institutional architecture of the EU\'s framework of financial supervision composed by three authorities: the <a href="/wiki/European_Banking_Authority" title="European Banking Authority">European Banking Authority</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Insurance_and_Occupational_Pensions_Authority" title="European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority">European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Securities_and_Markets_Authority" title="European Securities and Markets Authority">European Securities and Markets Authority</a>. To complement this framework, there is also a <a href="/wiki/European_Systemic_Risk_Board" title="European Systemic Risk Board">European Systemic Risk Board</a> under the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">ECB</a>. The aim of this financial control system is to ensure the economic stability of the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>To prevent the joining states from getting into financial trouble or crisis after entering the monetary union, they were obliged in the Maastricht treaty to fulfil important financial obligations and procedures, especially to show budgetary discipline and a high degree of sustainable economic convergence, as well as to avoid excessive government deficits and limit the government debt to a sustainable level.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry_and_digital_economy">Industry and digital economy</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Industry_and_Entrepreneurship" title="European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship">European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_corporate_law" title="European corporate law">European corporate law</a></div>\n<p>The European Commission working sectors are: Aeronautics, automotive, biotechnology, chemicals, construction, cosmetics, defense, electronics, firearms, food and drink, gambling, healthcare, maritime, mechanics, medical, postal, raw materials, space, textile, tourism, toys and <a href="/wiki/Social_economy" title="Social economy">Social economy</a> (<a href="/wiki/Societas_cooperativa_Europaea" title="Societas cooperativa Europaea">Societas cooperativa Europaea</a>).\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Energy policy of the European Union">Energy policy of the European Union</a></div>\n<div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">\n<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">\n<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">\n<tbody><tr source</td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">Origin</td>\n<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; style="padding:0 0.4em;vertical-align:bottom" align="right"><small>Imported</small></td>\n<td style="width:100px;border-left:solid 1px silver;border-right:solid 1px align="right"><small>Domestic</small></td>\n<td style="width:100px;border-left:solid 1px silver;border-right:solid 1px silver;">\n<div style="height:8px;width:7%;padding:0;margin:1px 0 4px; background:#71B600;color:red;overflow:hidden;font-size:4px;vertical-align:top">&#160;&#8195;</div>\n</td>\n<td style="padding:0 0.4em" align="right"><small>7%</small></td>\n</tr>\n  <tr style="line-height:100%">\n<td rowspan="2" style="padding:0 0.4em;min-width:8em">Other</td>\n<td style="padding:0 0.4em;vertical-align:bottom" align="right"><small>Imported</small></td>\n<td style="width:100px;border-left:solid 1px silver;border-right:solid 1px silver;vertical-align:bottom">\n<div style="height:8px;width:7%;padding:0;margin:0;background:#F4D49A;color:#F4D49A;overflow:hidden;font-size:4px;">&#160;&#8195;</div>\n</td>\n<td style="padding:0 0.4em;vertical-align:bottom" align="right"><small>7%</small></td>\n<td rowspan="2" style="width:3em;padding:0 0.4em" align="center"></td>\n</tr>\n<tr style="line-height:100%">\n<td style="padding:0 0.4em" align="right"><small>Domestic</small></td>\n<td style="width:100px;border-left:solid 1px silver;border-right:solid 1px silver;">\n<div style="height:8px;width:1%;padding:0;margin:1px 0 4px; background:#BBA47B;color:#F4D49A;overflow:hidden;font-size:4px;vertical-align:top">&#160;&#8195;</div>\n</td>\n<td style="padding:0 0.4em" align="right"><small>1%</small></td>\n</tr>\n\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg/300px-20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg/450px-20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg/600px-20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="635" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:20210125_Europe_Power_Sector_-_Renewables_vs_Fossil_Fuels_-_Climate_change.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 2020, renewables overtook fossil fuels as the European Union\'s main source of electricity for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-EmberEUpower_20210125_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EmberEUpower_20210125-278">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In 2006, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2005" title="Treaty of Accession 2005">EU-27</a> had a gross inland energy consumption of 1,825&#160;million tonnes of oil equivalent (toe).<sup id="cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EurostatEnergy-279">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> Around 46% of the energy consumed was produced within the member states while 54% was imported.<sup id="cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EurostatEnergy-279">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> In these statistics, nuclear energy is treated as <a href="/wiki/Primary_energy" title="Primary energy">primary energy</a> produced in the EU, regardless of the source of the uranium, of which less than 3% is produced in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Euratom2007_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euratom2007-280">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU has had legislative power in the area of energy policy for most of its existence; this has its roots in the original <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>. The introduction of a mandatory and comprehensive European energy policy was approved at the meeting of the European Council in October 2005, and the first draft policy was published in January 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Q&amp;A_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Q&amp;A-281">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU has five key points in its energy policy: increase competition in the <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">internal market</a>, encourage investment and boost interconnections between electricity grids; diversify energy resources with better systems to respond to a crisis; establish a new treaty framework for energy co-operation with Russia while improving relations with energy-rich states in Central Asia<sup id="cite_ref-oies_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oies-282">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> and North Africa; use existing energy supplies more efficiently while increasing <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Renewable energy commercialisation">renewable energy commercialisation</a>; and finally increase funding for new energy technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Q&amp;A_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Q&amp;A-281">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2007, EU countries as a whole imported 82% of their oil, 57% of their natural gas<sup id="cite_ref-low_carb_prop_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-low_carb_prop-283">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> and 97.48% of their uranium<sup id="cite_ref-Euratom2007_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euratom2007-280">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> demands. The three largest suppliers of natural gas to the European Union are Russia, Norway and <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, that amounted for about three quarters of the imports in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> There is a strong <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">dependence on Russian energy</a> that the EU has been attempting to reduce.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Russia_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Russia-285">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_the_European_Union" title="Transport in the European Union">Transport in the European Union</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Transport" title="European Commissioner for Transport">European Commissioner for Transport</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/170px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="128" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/255px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/340px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="\xc3\x98resund Bridge">\xc3\x96resund Bridge</a> between Denmark and Sweden is part of the <a href="/wiki/Trans-European_Networks" title="Trans-European Networks">Trans-European Networks</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The EU is working to improve cross-border infrastructure within the EU, for example through the <a href="/wiki/Trans-European_Networks" title="Trans-European Networks">Trans-European Networks</a> (TEN). Projects under TEN include the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, <a href="/wiki/LGV_Est" title="LGV Est">LGV Est</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9jus_Rail_Tunnel" title="Fr\xc3\xa9jus Rail Tunnel">Fr\xc3\xa9jus Rail Tunnel</a>, the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="\xc3\x98resund Bridge">\xc3\x96resund Bridge</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Brenner_Base_Tunnel" title="Brenner Base Tunnel">Brenner Base Tunnel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Messina_Bridge" title="Strait of Messina Bridge">Strait of Messina Bridge</a>. In 2010 the estimated network covers: 75,200 kilometres (46,700&#160;mi) of roads; 78,000 kilometres (48,000&#160;mi) of railways; 330 airports; 270 maritime harbours; and 210 internal harbours.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Europe" title="Rail transport in Europe">Rail transport in Europe</a> is being synchronised with the <a href="/wiki/European_Rail_Traffic_Management_System" title="European Rail Traffic Management System">European Rail Traffic Management System</a> (ERTMS), an initiative to greatly enhance safety, increase efficiency of trains and enhance cross-border interoperability of rail transport in Europe by replacing signalling equipment with digitised mostly wireless versions and by creating a single Europe-wide standard for train control and command systems.\n</p><p>The developing European transport policies will increase the pressure on the environment in many regions by the increased transport network. In the pre-2004 EU members, the major problem in transport deals with congestion and pollution. After the recent enlargement, the new states that joined since 2004 added the problem of solving accessibility to the transport agenda.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">Polish road network</a> was upgraded such as the <a href="/wiki/A4_autostrada_(Poland)" title="A4 autostrada (Poland)">A4 autostrada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications_and_space">Telecommunications and space</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_GNSS_Agency" title="European GNSS Agency">European GNSS Agency</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_(12052189474).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg/220px-Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg/330px-Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg/440px-Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_%2812052189474%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4256" data-file-height="2832" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Views_in_the_Main_Control_Room_(12052189474).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> Mission Control at <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Operations_Centre" title="European Space Operations Centre">ESOC</a> in <a href="/wiki/Darmstadt" title="Darmstadt">Darmstadt</a>, Germany</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Galileo_(satellite_navigation)" title="Galileo (satellite navigation)">Galileo positioning system</a> is another EU infrastructure project. Galileo is a proposed <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">Satellite navigation</a> system, to be built by the EU and launched by the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA). The Galileo project was launched partly to reduce the EU\'s dependency on the US-operated <a href="/wiki/Global_Positioning_System" title="Global Positioning System">Global Positioning System</a>, but also to give more complete global coverage and allow for greater accuracy, given the aged nature of the GPS system.<sup id="cite_ref-Barrot_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barrot-290">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_fisheries">Agriculture and fisheries</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/220px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/330px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/440px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vineyards in Romania; EU farms are supported by the <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">budgetary</a> expenditure.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a> (CAP) is one of the long lasting policies of the European Community.<sup id="cite_ref-stead_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stead-291">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> The policy has the objectives of increasing agricultural production, providing certainty in food supplies, ensuring a high quality of life for farmers, stabilising markets, and ensuring reasonable prices for consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;ac&#93;</a></sup> It was, until recently, operated by a system of subsidies and market intervention. Until the 1990s, the policy accounted for over 60% of the then <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Community</a>\'s annual budget, and as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Union&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> accounts for around 34%.<sup id="cite_ref-EU_CAP_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_CAP-293">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The policy\'s <a href="/wiki/Incomes_policy" title="Incomes policy">price controls</a> and market interventions led to considerable <a href="/wiki/Overproduction" title="Overproduction">overproduction</a>. These were <a href="/wiki/Buffer_stock_scheme" title="Buffer stock scheme">intervention stores</a> of products bought up by the Community to maintain minimum price levels. To dispose of surplus stores, they were often sold on the world market at prices considerably below Community guaranteed prices, or farmers were offered subsidies (amounting to the difference between the Community and world prices) to export their products outside the Community. This system has been criticised for under-cutting farmers outside Europe, especially those in the <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">developing world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_CAP_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_CAP-294">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> Supporters of CAP argue that the economic support which it gives to farmers provides them with a reasonable standard of living.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_CAP_294-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_CAP-294">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since the beginning of the 1990s, the CAP has been subject to a series of reforms. Initially, these reforms included the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Set-aside" title="Set-aside">set-aside</a> in 1988, where a proportion of farm land was deliberately withdrawn from production, milk quotas and, more recently, the \'de-coupling\' (or disassociation) of the money farmers receive from the EU and the amount they produce (by the Fischler reforms in 2004). Agriculture expenditure will move away from subsidy payments linked to specific produce, toward direct payments based on farm size. This is intended to allow the market to dictate production levels.<sup id="cite_ref-stead_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stead-291">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> One of these reforms entailed the modification of the EU\'s sugar regime, which previously divided the sugar market between member states and certain African-Caribbean nations with a privileged relationship with the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-EC_CAP_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EC_CAP-295">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Competition">Competition</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">European Union competition law</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Competition" title="European Commissioner for Competition">European Commissioner for Competition</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Docks" title="Silicon Docks">Silicon Docks</a></div>\n<p>The EU operates a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">competition policy</a> intended to ensure undistorted competition within the single market.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;ad&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Competition" title="European Commissioner for Competition">Competition Commissioner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_Vestager" title="Margrethe Vestager">Margrethe Vestager</a>, is one of the most powerful positions in the commission, notable for the ability to affect the commercial interests of trans-national corporations.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> For example, in 2001 the commission for the first time prevented a merger between two companies based in the United States (<a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">GE</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honeywell" title="Honeywell">Honeywell</a>) which had already been approved by their national authority.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> Another high-profile case <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Microsoft_competition_case" class="mw-redirect" title="European Union Microsoft competition case">against Microsoft</a>, resulted in the Commission fining <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> over \xe2\x82\xac777&#160;million following nine years of legal action.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Labour_market">Labour market</span></h3>\n<p>The EU seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 6.7% in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-unemployment_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unemployment-299">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> The euro area unemployment rate was 8.1%.<sup id="cite_ref-unemployment_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unemployment-299">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> Among the member states, the lowest unemployment rates were recorded in the Czech Republic (2.3%), Germany and Poland (both 3.4%), and the highest in Spain (14.9%) and Greece (19.0 in July 2018).<sup id="cite_ref-unemployment_299-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unemployment-299">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_policy_and_equality">Social policy and equality</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/European_Voluntary_Service" class="mw-redirect" title="European Voluntary Service">European Voluntary Service</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_labour_law" title="European labour law">European labour law</a></div>\n<table class="wikitable sortable collapsible plainrowheaders floatright" style="border: 0.5em; font-size: 90%; line-height: 0.9em; max-width: 20em;">\n<caption>EU
