src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">16.1\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope="row"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/23px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/35px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Flag_of_Ireland.svg/46px-Flag_of_Ireland.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;">13.4\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The EU has long sought to mitigate the effects of free markets by protecting workers rights and preventing social and environmental dumping. To this end it has adopted laws establishing minimum employment and environmental standards. These included the <a href="/wiki/Working_Time_Directive" class="mw-redirect" title="Working Time Directive">Working Time Directive</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Impact_Assessment_Directive_2011" title="Environmental Impact Assessment Directive 2011">Environmental Impact Assessment Directive</a>.\n</p><p>The EU has also sought to coordinate the social security and health systems of member states to facilitate individuals exercising free movement rights and to ensure they maintain their ability to access social security and health services in other member states. Social security main legislation is found in the Equal Treatment in Occupational Social Security Directive 86/378, the Equal Treatment in Social Security Directive 79/7/EEC, the Social Security Regulation 1408/71/EC and 883/2004/EC and the Directive 2005/36/EC\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Social_Charter" title="European Social Charter">European Social Charter</a> is the main body that recognizes the social rights of European citizens.\n</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/European_unemployment_insurance" title="European unemployment insurance">European unemployment insurance</a> has been proposed among others by the commissioner of Jobs <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Schmit" title="Nicolas Schmit">Nicolas Schmit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> A European Directive about Minimum Wage has also been discussed<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since 2019 there is a European Commissioner for Equality; a <a href="/wiki/European_Institute_for_Gender_Equality" title="European Institute for Gender Equality">European Institute for Gender Equality</a> has existed since 2007.\n</p><p>In 2020, the first ever European Union Strategy on LGBTIQ equality was approved under <a href="/wiki/Helena_Dalli" title="Helena Dalli">Helena Dalli</a> mandate.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Housing, youth, childhood, Functional diversity or elderly care are supportive competencies of the European Union and can be financed by the European Social Fund.\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_and_local_policy">Regional and local policy</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Regional_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Regional policy of the European Union">Regional policy of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Committee_of_the_Regions" title="European Committee of the Regions">European Committee of the Regions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_Investment_Bank" title="European Investment Bank">European Investment Bank</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_regional_policy_2014.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/European_regional_policy_2014.svg/220px-European_regional_policy_2014.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/European_regional_policy_2014.svg/330px-European_regional_policy_2014.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/European_regional_policy_2014.svg/440px-European_regional_policy_2014.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="609" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_regional_policy_2014.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Classification of regions from 2014 to 2020.</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Funds" class="mw-redirect" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds">Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds</a> are supporting the development of underdeveloped regions of the EU. Such regions are primarily located in the states of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">central</a> and southern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Business2000_Funds_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Business2000_Funds-305">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Several funds provide emergency aid, support for candidate members to transform their country to conform to the EU\'s standard (<a href="/wiki/Phare" title="Phare">Phare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Instrument_for_Structural_Policies_for_Pre-Accession" title="Instrument for Structural Policies for Pre-Accession">ISPA</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Special_Accession_Programme_for_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development" title="Special Accession Programme for Agriculture and Rural Development">SAPARD</a>), and support to the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (<a href="/wiki/Technical_Aid_to_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Technical Aid to the Commonwealth of Independent States">TACIS</a>). TACIS has now become part of the worldwide <a href="/wiki/EuropeAid_Co-operation_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="EuropeAid Co-operation Office">EuropeAid</a> programme.\n</p><p>Demographic transition to a society of aging population, low fertility-rates and depopulation of non-metropolitan regions is tackled within this policies.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment_and_climate">Environment and climate</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_the_Environment" title="European Commissioner for the Environment">European Commissioner for the Environment</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Climate_Change_Programme" title="European Climate Change Programme">European Climate Change Programme</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_LIFE_Programme" title="The LIFE Programme">The LIFE Programme</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/220px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/330px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/440px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="361" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">Biogeographic regions</a> of the continental European Union, according to the <a href="/wiki/European_Environment_Agency" title="European Environment Agency">European Environmental Agency</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In 1957, when the EEC was founded, it had no environmental policy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012-306">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> Over the past 50 years, an increasingly dense network of legislation has been created, extending to all areas of environmental protection, including air pollution, water quality, waste management, nature conservation, and the control of chemicals, industrial hazards, and biotechnology.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012_306-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012-306">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_European_Environmental_Policy" title="Institute for European Environmental Policy">Institute for European Environmental Policy</a>, environmental law comprises over 500 Directives, Regulations and Decisions, making environmental policy a core area of European politics.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-307">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>European policy-makers originally increased the EU\'s capacity to act on environmental issues by defining it as a trade problem.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012_306-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012-306">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup>\n<a href="/wiki/Trade_barrier" title="Trade barrier">Trade barriers</a> and competitive distortions in the Common Market could emerge due to the different environmental standards in each member state.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> In subsequent years, the environment became a formal policy area, with its own policy actors, principles and procedures. The legal basis for EU environmental policy was established with the introduction of the Single European Act in 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_307-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-307">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Initially, EU environmental policy focused on Europe. More recently, the EU has demonstrated leadership in global environmental governance, e.g. the role of the EU in securing the ratification and coming into force of the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a> despite opposition from the United States. This international dimension is reflected in the EU\'s Sixth Environmental Action Programme,<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> which recognises that its objectives can only be achieved if key international agreements are actively supported and properly implemented both at EU level and worldwide. The Lisbon Treaty further strengthened the leadership ambitions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012_306-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJordanAdelle2012-306">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> EU law has played a significant role in improving habitat and species protection in Europe, as well as contributing to improvements in air and water quality and waste management.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_307-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-307">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Mitigating <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> is one of the top priorities of EU environmental policy. In 2007, member states agreed that, in the future, 20% of the energy used across the EU must be <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable</a>, and carbon dioxide emissions have to be lower in 2020 by at least 20% compared to 1990 levels.<sup id="cite_ref-EUO_energy_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUO_energy-310">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> The EU has adopted an <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emissions trading system</a> to incorporate <a href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon emissions">carbon emissions</a> into the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Green_Capital" class="mw-redirect" title="European Green Capital">European Green Capital</a> is an annual award given to cities that focuses on the environment, energy efficiency, and quality of life in urban areas to create <a href="/wiki/Smart_city" title="Smart city">smart city</a>.\n</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Elections_to_the_European_Parliament" title="Elections to the European Parliament">Elections to the European Parliament</a> in 2019, the green parties increased their power, possibly because of the rise of post materialist values.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Proposals to reach a zero carbon economy in the European Union by 2050 were suggested in 2018 \xe2\x80\x93 2019. Almost all member states supported that goal at an EU summit in June 2019. The Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, and Poland disagreed.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2017, the EU emitted 9.1% of global <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse-gas_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Greenhouse-gas emissions">greenhouse-gas emissions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Global_Emissions_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Emissions-314">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> The EU has a target of zero <a href="/wiki/GHG_emission" class="mw-redirect" title="GHG emission">GHG emission</a> by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_research">Education and research</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Educational_policies_and_initiatives_of_the_European_Union" title="Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union">Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Holbein-erasmus.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/170px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/255px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/340px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1618" data-file-height="2290" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Holbein-erasmus.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Erasmus" title="Erasmus">Erasmus of Rotterdam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">Renaissance humanist</a> after whom the <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Programme" title="Erasmus Programme">Erasmus Programme</a> is named</div></div></div>\n<p>Basic education is an area where the EU\'s role is limited to supporting national governments. In higher education, the policy was developed in the 1980s in programmes supporting exchanges and mobility. The most visible of these has been the <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Programme" title="Erasmus Programme">Erasmus Programme</a>, a university exchange programme which began in 1987. In its first 20&#160;years, it supported international exchange opportunities for well over 1.5&#160;million university and college students and became a symbol of European student life.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>There are similar programmes for school pupils and teachers, for trainees in <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">vocational education and training</a>, and for adult learners in the <a href="/wiki/Lifelong_Learning_Programme_2007%E2%80%932013" title="Lifelong Learning Programme 2007\xe2\x80\x932013">Lifelong Learning Programme 2007\xe2\x80\x932013</a>. These programmes are designed to encourage a wider knowledge of other countries and to spread good practices in the education and training fields across the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> Through its support of the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_Process" title="Bologna Process">Bologna Process</a>, the EU is supporting comparable standards and compatible degrees across Europe.\n</p><p>Scientific development is facilitated through the EU\'s <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">Framework Programmes</a>, the first of which started in 1984. The aims of EU policy in this area are to co-ordinate and stimulate research. The independent <a href="/wiki/European_Research_Council" title="European Research Council">European Research Council</a> allocates EU funds to European or national research projects.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> EU <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">research and technological framework programmes</a> deal in a number of areas, for example energy where the aim is to develop a diverse mix of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> to help the environment and to reduce dependence on imported fuels.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care_and_food_safety">Health care and food safety</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Europe" title="Healthcare in Europe">Healthcare in Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_Health_and_Food_Safety" title="Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety">Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg/170px-EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg/255px-EHIC_Slovenia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg/340px-EHIC_Slovenia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="414" data-file-height="269" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/European_Health_Insurance_Card" title="European Health Insurance Card">European Health Insurance Card</a> (Slovenian version pictured)</div></div></div>\n<p>The EU has no major competences in the field of health care and Article 35 of the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a> affirms that "A high level of human health protection shall be ensured in the definition and implementation of all Union policies and activities". The <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_Health_and_Consumers_(European_Commission)" class="mw-redirect" title="Directorate-General for Health and Consumers (European Commission)">Directorate-General for Health and Consumers</a> seeks to align national laws on the protection of people\'s health, on the consumers\' rights, on the safety of food and other products.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>All EU and many other European countries offer their citizens a free <a href="/wiki/European_Health_Insurance_Card" title="European Health Insurance Card">European Health Insurance Card</a> which, on a reciprocal basis, provides insurance for emergency medical treatment insurance when visiting other participating European countries.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> A directive on cross-border healthcare aims at promoting co-operation on health care between member states and facilitating access to safe and high-quality cross-border healthcare for European patients.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The EU has some of the highest levels of life expectancy in the world, with Spain, Italy, Sweden, France, Malta, Ireland, Netherlands, Luxembourg, and Greece all among the world\'s top 20 countries with the highest life expectancy.<sup id="cite_ref-hdr-life-exp_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdr-life-exp-328">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> In general, life expectancy is lower in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> than in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> In 2018, the EU region with the highest life expectancy was <a href="/wiki/Comunidad_de_Madrid" class="mw-redirect" title="Comunidad de Madrid">Madrid</a>, Spain at 85.2 years, followed by the Spanish regions of <a href="/wiki/La_Rioja_(Spain)" class="mw-redirect" title="La Rioja (Spain)">La Rioja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Castilla y Le\xc3\xb3n">Castilla y Le\xc3\xb3n</a> both at 84.3 years, <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">Trentino</a> in Italy at 84.3 years and <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="\xc3\x8ele-de-France">\xc3\x8ele-de-France</a> in France at 84.2 years. The overall life expectancy in the EU in 2018 was 81.0 years, higher than the World average of 72.6 years.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">Culture of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Film_Awards" title="European Film Awards">European Film Awards</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Cultural policies of the European Union">Cultural policies of the European Union</a></div>\n<p>Cultural co-operation between member states has been an interest of the EU since its inclusion as a community competency in the Maastricht Treaty.<sup id="cite_ref-Bozoki_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bozoki-331">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> Actions taken in the cultural area by the EU include the <a href="/wiki/Culture_2000" title="Culture 2000">Culture 2000</a> seven-year programme,<sup id="cite_ref-Bozoki_331-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bozoki-331">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/European_Cultural_Month" title="European Cultural Month">European Cultural Month</a> event,<sup id="cite_ref-Culture_Month_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Culture_Month-332">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> and orchestras such as the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Youth_Orchestra" title="European Union Youth Orchestra">European Union Youth Orchestra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture" title="European Capital of Culture">European Capital of Culture</a> programme selects one or more cities in every year to assist the <a href="/wiki/Sociocultural_evolution" title="Sociocultural evolution">cultural development</a> of that city.<sup id="cite_ref-Capital_Culture_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Capital_Culture-334">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Sport policies of the European Union">Sport policies of the European Union</a></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> is by far the most popular sport in the European Union by the number of registered players. The other sports with the most participants in clubs are tennis, basketball, swimming, athletics, golf, gymnastics, equestrian sports, handball, volleyball and sailing.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Sport is mainly the responsibility of the member states or other international organisations, rather than of the EU. There are some EU policies that have affected sport, such as the free movement of workers, which was at the core of the <a href="/wiki/Bosman_ruling" title="Bosman ruling">Bosman ruling</a> that prohibited national football leagues from imposing quotas on foreign players with European citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Boseman_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Boseman-336">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> requires any application of economic rules to take into account the specific nature of sport and its structures based on voluntary activity.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup> This followed lobbying by governing organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> and <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a>, due to objections over the application of free market principles to sport, which led to an increasing gap between rich and poor clubs.<sup id="cite_ref-IHT_RT_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IHT_RT-338">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> The EU does fund a programme for Israeli, Jordanian, Irish, and British football coaches, as part of the Football 4 Peace project.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Heritage_Label" title="European Heritage Label">European Heritage Label</a></div>\n<p>The flag used is the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">Flag of Europe</a>, which consists of a <a href="/wiki/Circle_of_stars" title="Circle of stars">circle of</a> 12 golden stars on a blue background. Originally designed in 1955 for the Council of Europe, the flag was adopted by the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a>, the predecessors of the present Union, in 1986. The Council of Europe gave the flag a symbolic description in the following terms,<sup id="cite_ref-36th_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36th-340">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup> though the official symbolic description adopted by the EU omits the reference to the "Western world":<sup id="cite_ref-1996guide_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1996guide-341">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Against the blue sky of the Western world, the stars symbolise the peoples of Europe in a form of a circle, the sign of union. The number of stars is invariably <a href="/wiki/12_(number)#Religion" title="12 (number)">twelve</a>, the figure twelve being the symbol of perfection and entirety.</p><div class="templatequotecite">\xe2\x80\x94&#8201;<cite>Council of Europe. Paris, 7\xe2\x80\x939 December 1955.</cite></div></blockquote>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_copy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Europa_copy.jpg/150px-Europa_copy.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Europa_copy.jpg/225px-Europa_copy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Europa_copy.jpg/300px-Europa_copy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1081" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_copy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Europa_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Europa (mythology)">Europa</a> and the Bull on a Greek vase, circa 480 BC. <a href="/wiki/Tarquinia_National_Museum" title="Tarquinia National Museum">Tarquinia National Museum</a>, Italy</div></div></div>\n<p><i><a href="/wiki/Motto_of_the_European_Union" title="Motto of the European Union">United in Diversity</a></i> was adopted as the motto of the Union in the year 2000, having been selected from <a href="/wiki/A_motto_for_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="A motto for Europe">proposals</a> submitted by school pupils.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESimons2002110_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESimons2002110-342">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> Since 1985, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_day" class="mw-redirect" title="Flag day">flag day</a> of the Union has been <a href="/wiki/Europe_Day" title="Europe Day">Europe Day</a>, on 9 May (the date of the 1950 <a href="/wiki/Schuman_declaration" class="mw-redirect" title="Schuman declaration">Schuman declaration</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Anthem_of_Europe" title="Anthem of Europe">anthem of the Union</a> is an instrumental version of the prelude to the <i><a href="/wiki/Ode_to_Joy" title="Ode to Joy">Ode to Joy</a></i>, the 4th movement of <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/Symphony_No._9_(Beethoven)" title="Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)">ninth symphony</a>. The anthem was adopted by European Community leaders in 1985 and has since been played on official occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup>\nBesides naming the continent, the <a href="/wiki/Greek_mythology" title="Greek mythology">Greek mythological</a> figure of <a href="/wiki/Europa_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Europa (mythology)">Europa</a> has frequently been employed as a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">personification</a> of Europe. Known from the myth in which <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> seduces her in the guise of a white bull, Europa has also been referred to in relation to the present Union. Statues of Europa and the bull decorate several of the Union\'s institutions and a portrait of her is seen on the 2013 series of <a href="/wiki/Euro_banknotes" title="Euro banknotes">Euro banknotes</a>. The bull is, for its part, depicted on all residence permit cards.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDemey2007387_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDemey2007387-344">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charles the Great</a>, also known as Charlemagne (<a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">Carolus Magnus</i>) and later recognised as <i>Pater Europae</i> ("Father of Europe"),<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-345">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup> has a symbolic relevance to Europe. The commission has named <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne_building" title="Charlemagne building">one of its central buildings</a> in Brussels after Charlemagne and the city of <a href="/wiki/Aachen" title="Aachen">Aachen</a> has since 1949 awarded the <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne_Prize" title="Charlemagne Prize">Charlemagne Prize</a> to champions of European unification.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> Since 2008, the organisers of this prize, in conjunction with the European Parliament, have awarded the <a href="/wiki/European_Charlemagne_Youth_Prize" title="European Charlemagne Youth Prize">Charlemagne Youth Prize</a> in recognition of similar efforts led by young people.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_the_European_Union" title="Media freedom in the European Union">Media freedom in the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Broadcasting_Union" title="European Broadcasting Union">European Broadcasting Union</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/220px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/330px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/440px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1366" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Euronews" title="Euronews">Euronews</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a>, France</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Media_freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="Media freedom">Media freedom</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights" title="Fundamental rights">fundamental right</a> that applies to all <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a> of the European Union and its <a href="/wiki/EU_citizens" class="mw-redirect" title="EU citizens">citizens</a>, as defined in the <a href="/wiki/EU_Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights" class="mw-redirect" title="EU Charter of Fundamental Rights">EU Charter of Fundamental Rights</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eprs_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eprs-350">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>1</span></sup> Within the <a href="/wiki/EU_enlargement" class="mw-redirect" title="EU enlargement">EU enlargement</a> process, guaranteeing media freedom is named a "key indicator of a country\'s readiness to become part of the EU".<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The majority of media in the European Union are national-oriented, although some EU-wide media focusing on European affairs have emerged since the early 1990s, such as <a href="/wiki/Euronews" title="Euronews">Euronews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurosport" title="Eurosport">Eurosport</a>, <a href="/wiki/EUobserver" title="EUobserver">EUobserver</a>, <a href="/wiki/EURACTIV" class="mw-redirect" title="EURACTIV">EURACTIV</a> or <a href="/wiki/Politico_Europe" title="Politico Europe">Politico Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arte" title="Arte">ARTE</a> is a public Franco-German TV network that promotes programming in the areas of culture and the arts. 80% of its programming are provided in equal proportion by the two member companies, while the remainder is being provided by the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Interest_Grouping" class="mw-redirect" title="European Economic Interest Grouping">European Economic Interest Grouping</a> <i>ARTE GEIE</i> and the channel\'s European partners.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/MEDIA_Programme" class="mw-redirect" title="MEDIA Programme">MEDIA Programme</a> of the European Union has supported the European popular film and audiovisual industries since 1991. It provides support for the development, promotion and distribution of European works within Europe and beyond.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Impact">Impact</span></h2>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/170px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/255px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/340px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="2816" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">European emblem</a> emblazoned on the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The European Union has had a significant positive economic impact on most member states.<sup id="cite_ref-JoME_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JoME-356">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup> According to a 2019 study of the member states who joined from 1973 to 2004, "without European integration, per capita incomes would have been, on average, approximately 10% lower in the first ten years after joining the EU."<sup id="cite_ref-JoME_356-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JoME-356">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup> Greece was the exception reported by the study, which analysed up to 2008, "to avoid confounding effects from the global financial crisis".<sup id="cite_ref-JoME_356-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JoME-356">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The European Union has contributed to peace in Europe, in particular by pacifying border disputes,<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> and to the spread of democracy, especially by encouraging democratic reforms in aspiring Eastern European member states after the collapse of the USSR.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:2_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-360">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> Scholar <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Risse" title="Thomas Risse">Thomas Risse</a> wrote in 2009, "there is a consensus in the literature on Eastern Europe that the EU membership perspective had a huge anchoring effects for the new democracies."<sup id="cite_ref-:2_360-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-360">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/R._Daniel_Kelemen" title="R. Daniel Kelemen">R. Daniel Kelemen</a> argues that the EU has proved beneficial to leaders who are overseeing <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a>, as the EU is reluctant to intervene in domestic politics, gives authoritarian governments funds which they can use to strengthen their regimes, and because freedom of movement within the EU allows dissenting citizens to leave their backsliding countries. At the same time, the union provides an external constraint that prevents soft authoritarian regimes from progressing into hard dictatorships.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright">\n<ul>\n<li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/32px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/48px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 1.5x, title="Portal:European Union">European Union portal</a></span></li>\n<li><span><img alt="map" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-Europe_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541" /></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Europe" title="Portal:Europe">Europe portal</a></span></li></ul></div>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_the_European_Union" title="Outline of the European Union">Outline of the European Union</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Special_member_state_territories_and_the_European_Union" title="Special member state territories and the European Union">Special member state territories and the European Union</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_country_groupings" title="List of country groupings">List of country groupings</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_multilateral_free-trade_agreements" title="List of multilateral free-trade agreements">List of multilateral free-trade agreements</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Euroscepticism" title="Euroscepticism">Euroscepticism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Pan-European_nationalism" title="Pan-European nationalism">Pan-European nationalism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Brexit_withdrawal_agreement" title="Brexit withdrawal agreement">Brexit withdrawal agreement</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/European_Union%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_free_trade_agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="European Union\xe2\x80\x93United Kingdom free trade agreement">European Union\xe2\x80\x93United Kingdom free trade agreement</a></li></ul>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">\n</div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734"/><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha" style="column-width: 30em;">\n<ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 24 languages are equally official and accepted as working languages. Three of them \xe2\x80\x93 English, French and German \xe2\x80\x93 have the higher status of <i>procedural languages</i> and are used in the day-to-day workings of the European institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-procedural_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-procedural-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">With the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Special_member_state_territories_and_the_European_Union#Outermost_regions" title="Special member state territories and the European Union">outermost regions</a> observe different time zones not shown: <a href="/wiki/Martinique" title="Martinique">Martinique</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guadeloupe" title="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collectivity_of_Saint_Martin" title="Collectivity of Saint Martin">Saint Martin</a> (UTC\xe2\x88\x924); <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a> (UTC\xe2\x88\x923); <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</a> (UTC\xe2\x88\x921 / UTC); <a href="/wiki/Mayotte" title="Mayotte">Mayotte</a> (UTC+3); and <a href="/wiki/La_R%C3%A9union" class="mw-redirect" title="La R\xc3\xa9union">La R\xc3\xa9union</a> (UTC+4); which, other than the Azores, do not observe DST.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">.eu is representative of the whole of the EU; member states also have their own TLDs.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This figure is from February 2020, and takes account of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union. The population of the UK is roughly 0.9% of the world\'s population.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Frankish Empire has had a symbolic relevance for the building of Europe since the 20th century: <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> is often regarded as the "Father of Europe" and a similarity between the borders of Charlemagne\'s Empire and that of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> was made explicit during the 1965 Aachen exhibition sponsored by the Council of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> Kikuchi Yoshio (\xe8\x8f\x8a\xe6\xb1\xa0\xe8\x89\xaf\xe7\x94\x9f) of&#160;<a href="/wiki/Meiji_University" title="Meiji University">Meiji University</a>&#160;suggested that the notion of&#160;<a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>&#160;as a federal political entity influenced the later structural ideas of the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Native language</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-102">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">EU citizens able to hold a conversation in this language</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See Articles 165 and 166 (ex Articles 149 and 150) of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>, on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2010:083:0047:0200:EN:PDF">eur-lex.europa.eu</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Slavic: <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>. Baltic: <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">Romanian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">Dutch</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-116">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On <span data-sort-value="000000001990-10-03-0000" style="white-space:nowrap">3 October 1990</span>, the constituent states of the former <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">German Democratic Republic</a> <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">acceded</a> to the <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a>, automatically becoming part of the EU.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Area.and.population.figure-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Area.and.population.figure_142-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This figure includes the extra-European territories of member states which are part of the European Union, and excludes the European territories of member states which are not part of the Union. For more information see <a href="/wiki/Special_member_state_territories_and_the_European_Union" title="Special member state territories and the European Union">Special member state territories and the European Union</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-art249-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-art249_185-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-art249_185-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">See Article 288 (ex Article 249 TEC) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2010:083:0047:0200:EN:PDF">eur-lex.europa.eu</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Direct_Effect-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Direct_Effect_186-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the principle of Direct Effect first invoked in the Court of Justice\'s decision in <cite><i><a href="/wiki/Van_Gend_en_Loos_v_Nederlandse_Administratie_der_Belastingen" title="Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen">Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen</a></i></cite>,&#32;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61962J0026:EN:NOT">&#32;Eur-Lex</a>&#32;(European Court of Justice&#32;1963). See: Craig and de B\xc3\xbarca, ch. 5.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Supremacy-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Supremacy_188-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the principle of <a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_European_Union#Supremacy" class="mw-redirect" title="Law of the European Union">Supremacy</a> as established by the ECJ in Case 6/64, <i>Falminio Costa v. ENEL</i> [1964] ECR 585. See Craig and de B\xc3\xbarca, ch. 7. See also: <a href="/wiki/Factortame_litigation" class="mw-redirect" title="Factortame litigation">Factortame litigation</a>: <i>Factortame Ltd. v. Secretary of State for Transport (No. 2) [1991] 1 AC 603</i>, <i>Solange II</i> (<i>Re Wuensche Handelsgesellschaft</i>, BVerfG decision of 22 October 1986 [1987] 3 CMLR 225,265) and <i>Frontini v. Ministero delle Finanze</i> [1974] 2 CMLR 372; <i>Raoul George Nicolo</i> [1990] 1 CMLR 173.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-198">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">and is effectively treated as one of the Copenhagen criteria.<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/AdoptedText/ta08/ERES1610.htm">Assembly.coe.int.</a> This is a political and not a legal requirement for membership. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080626175941/http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta08%2FERES1610.htm">Archived</a> 26 June 2008 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-199">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The European Convention on Human Rights was previously only open to members of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/en/Treaties/Html/005.htm">Article 59.1 of the Convention</a>), and even now only states may become member of the Council of Europe (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/en/Treaties/Html/001.htm">Article 4 of the Statute of the Council of Europe</a>).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-200"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-200">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Opinion (2/92) of the European Court of Justice on "Accession by the Community to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms" <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61994V0002:FR:NOT">1996 E.C.R. I-1759</a> (in French), ruled that the European Community did not have the competence to accede to the ECHR.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See: Case 34/73, <i>Variola v. Amministrazione delle Finanze</i> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61973J0034:EN:NOT">[1973] ECR 981</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-204">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">To do otherwise would require the drafting of legislation which would have to cope with the frequently divergent legal systems and administrative systems of all of the now 28 member states. See Craig and de B\xc3\xbarca, p. 115</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-art39/141_Rome-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-art39/141_Rome_213-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See Articles 157 (ex Article 141) of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>, on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2010:083:0013:0046:EN:PDF">eur-lex.europa.eu</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-art2(7)_Amsterdam-214"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-art2(7)_Amsterdam_214-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See Article 2(7) of the <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Amsterdam Treaty">Amsterdam Treaty</a> on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/en/treaties/dat/11997D/htm/11997D.html#0001010001">eur-lex.europa.eu</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080217024604/http://eur-lex.europa.eu/en/treaties/dat/11997D/htm/11997D.html#0001010001">Archived</a> 17 February 2008 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-215">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Council Directive 2000/43/EC of 29 June 2000 implementing the principle of equal treatment between persons irrespective of racial or ethnic origin (OJ L 180, 19 July 2000, pp. 22\xe2\x80\x9326); Council Directive 2000/78/EC of 27 November 2000 establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation (OJ L 303, 2 December 2000, pp. 16\xe2\x80\x9322).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-273">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style Those <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_EU" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaties of the EU">two Treaties</a> shall have the same legal value. The Union shall replace and succeed the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="European Community">European Community</a>".</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/databrowser/view/tps00001/default/table?lang=en">[1]</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/weo-database/2020/October/weo-report?a=1&amp;c=998,&amp;s=NGDPD,PPPGDP,PPPPC,&amp;sy=2019&amp;ey=2025&amp;ssm=0&amp;scsm=1&amp;scc=0&amp;ssd=1&amp;ssc=0&amp;sic=0&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1">"World Economic Outlook Database, October 2020"</a>. <i>IMF.org</i>. Heritage and shared histories in the European Union"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Tijdschrift voor Economische en Sociale Geografie</i>. <b>98</b> (3): 411. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1467-9663.2007.00406.x">10.1111/j.1467-9663.2007.00406.x</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1467-9663">1467-9663</a>. <q>For the last two thousand years, the Christian church has attempted to unify Europe in cultural terms. Christianity did not originate in Europe but, building upon the organisation of the Roman Empire, has tried throughout the Middle Ages to become a Europe-wide organisation.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Tijdschrift+voor+Economische+en+Sociale+Geografie&amp;rft.atitle=A+European+Cultural+Identity%3F+Heritage+and+shared+histories+in+the+European+Union&amp;rft.volume=98&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=411&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fj.1467-9663.2007.00406.x&amp;rft.issn=1467-9663&amp;rft.aulast=Gorp&amp;rft.aufirst=Bouke+Van&amp;rft.au=Renes%2C+Hans&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fresearch.vu.nl%2Fws%2Ffiles%2F2331638%2F208641.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200289-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagdenHamilton200289_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPagdenHamilton2002">Pagden &amp; Hamilton 2002</a>, p.&#160;89.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMather200616\xe2\x80\x9318-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMather200616\xe2\x80\x9318_38-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMather2006">Mather 2006</a>, pp.&#160;16\xe2\x80\x9318.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFNelsenGuth2015" class="citation book cs1">Nelsen, Brent F.; Guth, James L. (2015). <i>Religion and the Struggle for European Union: Confessional Culture and the Limits of Integration</i>. Eurostat. 10 July 2008. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/pls/portal/docs/PAGE/PGP_PRD_CAT_PREREL/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008_MONTH_07/8-10072008-EN-AP.PDF">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 23 September 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 September</span> 2008</span>. <q><br /> In the EU27, gross inland energy consumption was 1 825&#160;million tonnes of oil equivalent (toe) in 2006, stable compared with 2005, while energy production decreased by 2.3% to 871 mn toe&#160;...<br /> Gross inland consumption is defined as primary production plus imports, recovered products and stock change, less exports and fuel supply to maritime bunkers (for seagoing ships of all flags)&#160;... <br /> A tonne of oil equivalent (toe) is a standardised unit defined on the basis of one tonne of oil having a net calorific value of 41.868 Gigajoules.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Energy+consumption+and+production%3A+EU27+energy+dependence+rate+at+54%25+in+2006%3A+Energy+consumption+stable&amp;rft.pub=Eurostat&amp;rft.date=2008-07-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fepp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu%2Fpls%2Fportal%2Fdocs%2FPAGE%2FPGP_PRD_CAT_PREREL%2FPGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008%2FPGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008_MONTH_07%2F8-10072008-EN-AP.PDF&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Euratom2007-280"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Euratom2007_280-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Euratom2007_280-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/euratom/ar/last.pdf">"EU supply and demand for nuclear fuels"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Euratom Supply Agency \xe2\x80\x93 Annual Report 2007</i>. (2001)</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Directive_on_the_re-use_of_public_sector_information" title="Directive on the re-use of public sector information">Directive on the re-use of public sector Sakharov">Andrei Sakharov</a></span></li></ul>\n</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">1976\xe2\x80\x932000</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even"
